1998: Mistook first little face monkey as friendly.
2015: Mistook first little HD face monkey as friendly.

1998: Mistook first bullsquid as friendly for killing evil face monkeys.
2015: Mistook first HD bullsquid as friendly for killing evil HD face monkeys.

1998: Mistook first Marine as friendly for I ran ahead of evacuating scientist.
2015: Mistook first HD Marine as friendly for I ran ahead of evacuating HD scientist.

1998: Mistook missle launch as me starting WWIII since I forgot why I was doing it.
2015: Mistook HD missle launch as me starting WWIII since I forgot why I was doing it.

1998: Mistook out of control freight car for turboing; died from impact against wall.
2015: Mistook out of control HD freight car for turboing; died from impact against HD wall.

1998: Mistook itchysaour as shadow; died from fright.
2015: Mistook HD itchysaour as HD shadow; died from fright in HD.

TL;DR
1998: I crowbar'd a lot of things.
2015: I crowbar'd a lot of things in HD.

10/10 keeps to source material, bringing lots of memories and crowbars.


Edit:
I swear I will keep updating this review as much as I want, because I keep running into nostalgia.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a remake done right, it respects it's source material and improves upon it greatly.

I'm a big fan of the original Half-Life, as are most if not all people interested in this remake I guess, my expectations were high.. and pretty much all of them were met or even exceeded.

This isn't just Half-Life with HD textures slapped onto it, this is a total remake that has been in the making since 2005, you have to respect the developers for passionately working on the mod for that long, that alone deserves supporting them by buying this game in my opinion.

If you've played original, the levels will feel familiar but fresh thanks to the heavily upgraded visuals, additions of some new areas and even a new soundtrack which is outstanding too.
Some areas have been tweaked to improve gameplay, the most apparent example of this would be the chapter 'on a rail' which no longer has you going in circles several times, though the old version is downloadable from the workshop.
Another thing that felt is worth noting as a huge improvement is the fact that the scientists and guards no longer feel like robots, but more like actual people stuck in the same mess as you with more dialogue and emotions.

However, the game is still in early access, the final chapters of the game which are set in the Xen borderworld are still missing, but I trust the developers to finish those too, I doubt they'd call it quits after all this time and having come so far.

So, is Black Mesa worth your money? absolutely, I had a blast revisiting Black Mesa, and I'm absolutely pumped for Xen!

Should one of the devs read this, absolutely amazing job on the HEV suit boot-up sequence, it gave me goosebumps!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE:Also see my:
Half-Life (1) Review
Half-Life 2 Review
Half-Life: Opposing Force Review
Half-Life: Blue Shift Review

TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Black Mesa is a first-person shooter game by the 'Black Mesa Modification Team' aka 'Crowbar Collective' serving as a total HD remake using the Source engine of Valve's critically acclaimed and award winning game Half-Life (1998). Although Black Mesa originally started out as a simple Half-Life 2 mod, it has since developed and evolved into its own standalone game.

Black Mesa still follows the original Half-Life 1 story (albeit with a few level redesigns) where the player takes on the role of Gordon Freeman, a scientist working for the Black Mesa Research Complex with a PhD in Theoretical Physics with an uncanny ability to wield human and alien military hardware. Follow him as he fights his way through the Black Mesa complex which is under siege from Alien invaders following an experiment gone horribly wrong and the military who's out to cover-up the incident.

PROS:+ Immense Graphical Improvement from the original game, such as, but not limited to:
High Resolution textures
Improved particle effects
Improved lighting effects
Good gun models and textures
Good animation quality
Good character models+ Improved immersion and atmosphere that brings the Black Mesa Complex to life such as, but not limited to:
New NPC to Player dialogues and new NPC to NPC conversations
Diverse NPC models including female scientist, guards and soldiers with varying uniforms and faces
Great sound effects
Revamped voices of Marines and Aliens (Vortigaunt)+ Great voice acting
+ The AI for Black Mesa Security Guards were significantly improved (they now have a better chance of survival than the Barney Calhoun clones from the original game.)..but... (See CON #6)
+ Cool soundtrack that plays on specific levels and events
+ The level redesigns opened several new small areas within the levels and chapters which encourages a bit of exploration
+ Customization options for multiplayer characters
+ Good game time (provided you're playing for immersion rather than a speed run)
+ Free version (Legacy Version) of Black Mesa is still available for download[www.blackmesasource.com]
+ Great over-all presentation
+ Steam Workshop Support

CONS:- Early Access (will remove after final release)
- Half-Life 'Xen' chapters are still missing (will remove when its completed)
- Longer than usual load times
- Walk button is not functioning properly
- Few minor graphical glitches (particularly, some blood stain on the hand and guns models don't disappear)
- The Marines and Scientist AI needs improvement (The Scientist Escort AI runs into line of fire instead of taking cover; In some occasions the enemy AI just stand around like turrets.)
- Some of the redesigned levels feels a bit shorter than the original versions. (To be more specific, 'Surface Tension' and 'On A Rail' chapters.

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME that does the legendary Half-Life franchise justice and Lord Gaben proud. Brought to us by a team of volunteer artists, coders and developers, Black Mesa proves that the formula of Half-Life can and will withstand the test of time.

Both fans of the old title and the next generation of gamers can once again visit the universe that revolutionized FPS gaming.

WORTH IT?:I can easily RECOMMEND this game even at its full price of $19.99 (or your regional equivalent). Black Mesa provides at least 8-10 hours of game time with one playthrough and is highly satisfying to finish.

A message from the devs to people who says “it's just a paid mod”: (This part is not necessary for the review)Originally posted by BMS | Hubicorn: Posted: 7 May @ 10:49pm
xxx We originally started out as a Mod for Half Life 2, releasing the first half of our modification in 2012 for free. Since then, we have evolved into a full, standalone game on a new hybrid engine while making vast improvements to the single player campaign. We are no longer a modification. We entered Early Access to gain support and make the commitment to finishing up the entire single player campaign, while introducing a slew of new updates along the way. Such as day one Multiplayer, Workshop, and Steam integration support.

With this comes costs such as licenses, hardware, and servers, that without being fulfilled, we would have not been able to release our product to our lovely fans. We aimed for the lowest price possible for Early Access given these circumstances. I hope this insight helps you.
---------------------------------------------------------

Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
Black Mesa is a fanbased remake about Half Life 1"
date: which was originaly made by ValvE. Planned and scripted from Crowbar Collective as a mod for Half Life 2 back in 2012
recommended: Black Mesa started to gain a huge fan base on modDB. Its highly detailed textures
hoursPlayed: revised graphics and new features gave the ageing rough gem a new cut and let the hearts from fans of this franchise leap of joy.\n\nOne year later Crowbar Collective got the opportunity to let the people decide on greenlight wether they would like to see this mod on steam or not. Much to the joy of everyone involved
voteText: Black Mesa was able to get so much support to finally find its way on steam. It turned out to be a standalone game with higher texture models as well as more features like a stunning multiplayer. On the 5th May of 2015 people were able to purchase Black Mesa at the steamstore in a still current Early Access
helpfulPercent:
caused from the fact that this game isn't finished yet.

Half Life itself is all about Gordon Freeman. A scientist who works at the Black Mesa Facility. An experiment -which was already foredoomed to fail- went wrong and unknown speciments are starting to take over the facility. Freeman's mission now: to save the facility and probably the whole world. And so his journey through a horde of aliens as well as friends and foes begins. Will Freeman be able to fullfil this destiny or will mankind be doomed?

As already mentioned the graphics are stunning. The game itself runs on the well-known source engine but the many details
votesHelpful: new animations and refurbished textures let the player re-experience the Half Life 1-world as never before. The uranium glows in toxic green
votesTotal: yellow-greenish goo and dark red blood sticks on Gordon Freeman's weapons and the radiation creates a sightable static; the developer haven't been stingy on the details for sure.\n\nNothing has changed gameplaywise
votesFunny:
this will keep the nostalgia up.

The soundtracks of the game are really remarkable. Joel Nielsen composed every single soundtrack you are able to listen to on the official Black Mesa Website as well as in the game of course. According to his own website he started composing for Black Mesa in 2004. Since 2014 he works on the soundtracks for the last missing levels named "XEN".

Sadly
commentsCount: the multiplayer gets rarely visited. A shame
column16: because even here the upgraded graphics and details find their use to fanmade maps. Anyway
column17: give it a try after you finished the singleplayer

it is worth the time!

Two weak things I have to mention at the end of this review:

Firstly
column19: the rising difficulty curve. What starts as a cake walk for the player
column20: ends in the middle of the game in a big carnage. Too many AIs will try to take down Freeman at once which ends not unusualy in a very frustrating death.\nSecondly
column21: the AI of allies. Guards
column22: as long as they follow you

column24:
they will unlikely try to open the door to follow you again. This leads to even more lonely walks together with many dead and trapped guards.


●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
This remake might be the best of this year. While reliving the nostalgia

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly, an opportunity to try before you invest
Firstly, to anyone concerned, the mod release of Black Mesa still remains available to the public at their Official Website[www.blackmesasource.com] (This Official Black Mesa Wiki Article[wiki.blackmesasource.com] has installation instructions).
You can also download the soundtrack by Joel Nielsen for free or for a donation of choice there too. (It's also on offer from various digital retailers, including Joel Nielsen's Bandcamp[joelnielsen.bandcamp.com] for loseless formats such as FLAC)

In addition, GAMEBANANA & ModDB still have the numerous community made addons for the mod such as the well received Black Mesa Animation Revamp (Whether they will arrive to the Steam Workshop is yet to be seen as of this review), so you have plenty of opportunity to freely see for yourself if Black Mesa is a game you wish to invest in during it's Early Access period.


Now, The Game
After receiving the still persisting development for just passed a decade and being one of the first titles to be given the Steam Greenlight, it's now finally here in an Early Access build. So the first question most would surely be asking is; What's the difference between the mod release I can still get

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A few friends have already asked for my opinion on this gam-MOD, IT'S A MOD. So, I decided to make a review about it instead of talking about it over and over. As usual, I'll talk first about the bad things, however there's not that many:

First and foremost; the controversy. I've waited for a long time to buy it because I was seriously against what the devs did. You see, time ago, this was a Mod. For free. The Devs had not yet finished it, but left it there for people to test it out. When they did that, they promised that Black Mesa would NEVER cost money, as it was a mod they created with passion to revive a game they love. Well that's kind of bullsh#t because soon after the game arrived in Steam Greenlight, and after a few months it was released in Early Access, still unfinished, and FOR 20€. A lot of people did NOT take this lightly, as it was a God-damn lie which they tried to hide from the Internet. In the end, I waited long for a sale, and I got it on the Autumm sale of 2015.

The second bad point of the game, is that after so many years in development, it's still unfinished. From the start to the Lambda complex, you'll get to see an insanely beautifull recreation of Half-Life, to then get hit in the face with a to be continued"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Headcrabs:  Check
Lack of ammo and frustrating level design: Check
Crowbar and guts: Check

A remake, well.. a remastering of the original Halflife would be a better description.  You won't recognize some parts of it since the upgrading did take away a bit of the nostalgia.  But, the heart and soul of the game is still there.  From double-backs from pointless dead-ends to unavoidable damage in blind turns from headcrabs to invulnerable helicopters.. it's all there!

The developers did a great job getting every little detail recaptured in high resolution down to the last exploding barrel.  Definitely a must-play if you've never played it before.  If you have, you'll be happy to know that it's just as fun as the original to play through and figure out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review has been updated on January 29th, 2015.

Okay, so this is going to be a long review.  So for those who want the short version:

This game is awesome, but I am disappointed of the progress made in development.  Still no Xen chapters since it has been on Steam. Buy it only if you feel like waiting for the game to be (possibly) finished.

--------------------

Now for the long version:

This game came out on Steam around May 7th, 2015 and was put in Early Access.  I bought the game May 17th, 2015.  Now,  I had played the game before it came onto Steam. The legacy version, that is the one.

The game was good fun and great memories came back to me.  Both versions felt the same to me at the time, but I figured we would be getting a finished game soon enough.  Oh, how I was wrong.

After the game had gotten some fair updates, I picked up and played the game again through, and found that the diffculty has been tweaked.  Ammo still felt abit scarce.  Weapons didn't feel as effective either.  Other than this, I honestly couldn't tell anything was different.  Marines felt more like aimbots from a distance suddenly too.

There was still no Xen chapters either.  I updated my review sometime in November from 'Thumbs Up' to 'Thumbs Down' and simply couldn't recommend buying it.

A December 2015 update was announced and I had to get hyped for it.  I mean, 6 months after it came to Steam.  Xen had to be finished and the game completed, right?

Disappoint. Again.  Mostly some bugs fixed, and cosmetic changes, again. (This includes weapon models, sounds, etc.)  Still no Xen Chapters and the developers seem quiet about its progress.

I notice quite a few updates to the Multiplayer, but I do not play it and I greatly feel like this feature shouldn't had been done until the Single Player game had actually been finished.  Maybe this is why Xen is taking so long to be given to us.  I do hope they redirect their focus to what is actually important.

--------------------

So, that's it.  In conclusion,  I hope this review and rant was informative and I will keep on updating this to reflect what I see and believe to be the state of the game. The game is definitely a very good remake of Half-Life. I am just disappointed about its development progress and just cannot fully recommend in buying, unless it is on sale.

Summary:Black Mesa is a fanmade remake of the original Half-Life by Valve. Even though it's not finished yet, it offers multiplayer maps and most of the Half-Life levels remade - Just Xen levels are missing. The original great level design and gameplay is made by Valve, but the remake itself (onto the HL2 Source engine) is made pretty well except some smaller bugs.

Pros:- Well-made remake. Plays as great as the original Half-Life, this can bring more people to this classic game, since the old graphics may not be appealing to current gamer generation. All gameplay features remains the same.

- Custom mods and Workshop support. So you can mod a mod.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

===VASTLY IMPROVED/NEW EXPIRIENCE===
The new Early Access Version of Black Mesa has seen major improvements and detail overhauls compared to the free version of BMS that came out a couple years ago from the time of this review writing. I've played every Half-Life game including the expansion packs for HL1, and while this game won't ever have the classic charm of the classic Half-Life, this HD port and it's creators exceeded my expectations for mod that seemed almost impossible to be true, I like HD overhauls of certain games, and the development team did very well with this, they deserve something for their hard work, and that's why I decided to buy this version, and needless to say, I wasn't expecting a more polished copy, so I was very happy and surprised from what I see in this version. I will describe below how this version is improved upon the original BMS to better help the reader decide if this is worth their buy or not.

===NEW AND IMPROVED/THINGS I LIKED===
-NOW HAS A WORKSHOP!!!!!! LET THE MODDING BEGIN!!!!

-Many level designs and Architecture and scenarios are greatly improved from the original BMS, in general, I like them, and they provide a new experience for me and doesn't make me feel like I'm just playing Half-Life 1 in HD, it forces you to come up with new ideas and ways of approaching certain obstacles and enemies, while keeping level design feel more immersive and realistic, almost as if you could role-play, it's just great.

-Sound Design Vastly Improved over BMS, many sounds have been refined a well as the adrenaline pumping soundtrack of this version, weapon sounds and NPC voices have also been slightly improved from what have seen so far, as well as level elements, and enemy idle sounds. A couple of examples would be the HEV suit with a new sound filter on the original voice making it feel more immersive and futuristic, fitting to the game very well, and other sound examples such as the guard post between the two doors leading to sector C, where the guard makes a comment on Gordon's ponytail removal, before his voice was heard as if he was next to you talking, and now he talks through a COM like filter while behind the window in the guard post, counting as a nice improved detail that even I missed to question in the original BMS.

-Some Weapons have seen new and improved balancing, better animations, new models, and more immersive details
while still keeping a balanced ammunition pool that's more realistic and adds more difficulty to the game. One example of a weapon overhaul would be the Glock-17 which now has a new model, scratched details to show wear and tear of being an old used gun, it's original functions from HL1 have returned, and normal fire shoots at the same speed as the original glock in Hl1, and has seen the return of it's famous Alt-Fire Rapid mode, and has very nice muzzle flash, and blowback animations, as well as new idle animations, and a cool sprint animation as you have it equipped.

-Much more dangerous combat at higher difficulty modes balancing out the loss of certain hard nonsense obstacles with the new realistic level designs implemented. Enemies are more quick, accurate, can quickly kill you in groups at close range, and are a lot harder to kill as you turn up the difficulty. The bullsquid for example used to be an enemy you could kill quickly at any range, but it now has much higher health, more damaging attacks, and it's spit attack has splash damage that can still be fatal, if most or all of it hits you, and almost more than one magazine of a glock can kill one on Normal assuming all hits land, and their close range attacks are still dangerously damaging, I now hate seeing bullsquids ever so more. And houndeyes not only can destroy you in large groups if allowed to attack in time, their attacks can optionally (can be toggled in settings) Ring your hearing and normally can disorient your vision with their sonic attacks, making it hard to aim and hear, thus making them also more formidable than before.

-I LOVED the new HEV visual intro as you pick up the suit, not only was there a new voice, but when the HEV is checking systems and analyzing defensive weapon selections and vital monitoring, it will show the pieces of the HUD that it is referring to, and use the HUD bloom accordingly to show everything, and will even give a detailed visual interpretation of the suit and the wearer's physical attributes and weight. I also LOVED the loading screens having new fun looks, and gameplay hints showing a really refined experience, and even details like that are what make a game nice to have.

===THINGS I HATED/THINGS THAT NEED A FIX/HOPE TO SEE===
-Some level hazards from the original game that could still be implemented and not hurt the realistic design are missing, one example is when you go through to restore the power for the blast pit, before you could see a puddle or water, and later it would be electrified forcing you to find a method to get across, or perhaps a new route or vent would be nice to see, but that's only my personal prefence on some of these level hazards, they don't have to be there but it does make some areas easier than they should have been.

-The crobar hitting speed is way too fast, it should be nerfed a bit slower, perhaps the same as HL1's crowbar, I love how the model and animations for the crowbar were improved and more enthusiastic, but the hit speed seems unrealistic and a bit overpowered, and encourages spamming to kill headcrabs rather than accurate timing for their jump trajectory.

-I'm excited to see Xen and anticipate it very much, this is not a con that it's not out yet, I understand the detail you developers want to implement and I say, Take all the time you need, it will be worth the wait for all of us.



===FINAL THOUGHTS===
-This game is very fun and it's a whole new experience for Half-Life lovers, even if it's not an official valve game, that doesn't mean it wasn't carefully worked on and detailed, and by the time the full version releases, we will see a very polished and fun game to play with lots of features, some being new over the older HL1, and BMS. Help this developer finish this game and give them what they deserve for their years of hard work and dedication, and enjoy the refreshed experience that even valve liked to see!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A brilliant reimagining of a timeless classic. If you've never played the half life series before but are turned off by the dated-ness this is a great way to get the same experience with a more modern feeling. It stays true to the original but it's also not a carbon copy.

For those of you who are familiar, this is not just a fresh coat of paint or some HD textures. It's the entire game redesigned and remastered. The levels and puzzles will be familiar, but the entire thing feels different; it's a totally new experience and  absolutely worth playing.

Now for the thing on everyone's mind: is it worth $20? As a standalone product, absolutely. It delivers enough content with the quality to justify that price tag.

The point of contention here is that the game was released earlier as a free mod. I haven't played much of the mod, but the money and valve's support here seems to have been used to take the mod a bit beyond what it could achieve as a mod alone - full use of the latest source engine, a multiplayer mode with steam workshop integration for maps, graphics and sound improved even further, gameplay stability improved greatly (I haven't encountered a single bug or glitch on my playthrough).

Certainly, this is an improved experience from the mod and not just the same thing with a price tag slapped on. I'm given to understand the devs have kept the mod release (now legacy version) available for free so it's up to you to decide whether $20 is a worthy asking price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For any and all Half-Life fans, this is fantastic. For any newcomers to the series, this is also fantastic, and you should seriously consider making this your entry into the series if you were put off by the original game's age.


Black Mesa is a re-make of Half-Life, that's true, but with the effort put into its development over eight-plus years it might as well be a whole new game. And all because they were dissatisfied with Valve porting it to their then-new physics engine in 2004. Pretty much every aspect has been remastered. Worskhop support lets you modify you experience easier than ever before.

If you're not familiar with Half-Life...that's okay. You don't have to be. But if you're looking for a solid FPS that doubles as a solid experience, with some brains, a lot of tension (bordering on survival horror at times) and even a little pathos up its sleeve? You could do far worse than this. Just play it on Normal or Easy, for reasons I explain below.

And hey, there's multiplayer included with good maps and decent netcode. It's quite similar to HL's deathmatch at HL2 Deathmatch speed, with a much wider range of player model choices. The actual gameplay is still old-school 'player who gets the best guns first gets to kill everyone quicker' for better or worse.


Okay, now for more technical details/notes for people who've played the mod's original release or the original Half-Life:

Maps have been streamlined from the mod's first launch and from Half-Life. The gameplay itself is different from HL in only one way: it's generally better. The previously mentioned Marines no longer quite resemble hideously overpowered Counter-Strike aimbots (which was a problem in the original release).

The only criticism that could be said of the campaign is that the devs made it noticeably harder than the original Half-Life. At times, this makes the game incredibly frustrating on Hard difficulty unless you follow an optimal strategy and know exactly what to expect for some areas. While classic HL had its difficult moments on Hard difficulty, I don't think it'd be unfair to say that some of BM's hardest moments more resemble tactical shooters like classic Rainbow Six/Ghost Recon. Although considering you're effectively playing Joe Schmoe Freeman, PhD and fighting highly trained US Marines, it might be fitting.

(Being able to land consistent crossbow headshots helps if you have ammunition for it; the energy weapons either come too late or are too weak to efficiently dispatch enemies with.)


BM's graphics, as you might know, could be described as an improvement. Every security guard no longer looks the same. There's actually women scientists now. The Marines have much better voice acting. The 'Black Mesa' tab in the options menu lets you configure a lot of the game's new graphical effects, such as sideways movement bob, revolver ironsights and houndeye tinnitus.

The music is pretty good. Not quite as iconic as the original music, but it definitely shines at times. Comprehensive Workshop mod support, map-making tools and Steamworks features are pretty alright too.

BM's most beautiful element to me, though, is the weaponry. The arsenal's feel is massively improved over the original mod's guns; every one of them is great in their own right. I'd say they even give the original game's weapons a good run for their money.


I already said the developers have put a huge amount of effort into this thing, but they aren't done, either. As of this writing, they're still working on a version of the final section of Half-Life that they said they wanted to make better than the original. There's also various physics bugs that I'm pretty sure they're working on.

Given all of this, Black Mesa is well worth paying for. And even if you didn't like Half-Life, I would recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is actually a pretty good game, even considering it's a remake of a game made back in 1998. Some areas of the Black Mesa Research Facility are actually different from the original, which can be very fresh and a new experience if you played and remembered the old Half-Life, however each area can still be compared to the original. While yes, there is a free mod version of this game, the paid version, even while still in early access, holds up much better than the mod version.  For example, I remember the mod version having much more difficult enemies because some of them (for example, the vortigaunts and the HECU troops) had the accuracy of a professionally trained hitman, while still dealing out a heavy amount of damage. While in this version, while they're accurate, their damage is a little less, still creating challenging enemies. Another reason this version's better than the mod version is because the mod version is never getting the final Xen levels due to an outdated version of the Source engine, the paid version is. My only complaint would be that I feel that the weapons are not as efficient as I remember them being, for example the .357 Magnum isn't as powerful on bodyshots as it used to be, and getting headshots during a hectic firefight between a military unit and damn aliens ain't easy.

Overall, despite being in early access, (the devs have stated that the Xen levels will come out in a future update), it's a really good game crafted with love and dedication to the original Half-Life. 9/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Black Mesa team made a considerable effort to make Half-Life look more like Half-Life 2- make the set pieces more realistic, with a thoughtful approach to how a research facility SHOULD look. Let’s be honest, we all thought Half-Life appeared “realistic” back in 1998, but when you play it today, character models look like walking legos and most level layouts made little sense. The point of Black Mesa was to correct that and it appears they do right out of the gate. I need to commend the Black Mesa team for realizing some implausible mistakes in the original opening. In Half-Life, there’s a portion of the track where a gate is lowered that requires the tram to stop to allow the passing of a robot carrying radioactive waste. Would a research facility really build a tram system low enough for this to even be in issue? In Black Mesa, the tram is far overhead as the spider-robot walks by and is merely a sightsee on opening tour. These little enhancements make the world of difference when revisiting New Mexico. Now we just need the ending.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It really really bugs me that people are using the paid mod scandal to put this game down. The free mod version was a mod. This is a GAME. There's a difference. Black Mesa: Source was a total conversion mod for half life 2, which required the base game to play. That's what makes a mod a mod. This is a standalone game that will from now on get the updates. To put it into perspective, Killing floor was a mod for Unreal tournament before it was a 20 dollar game and you asshats don't complain about that.

When I played Black Mesa as a free mod I was thrilled, and when the standalone version came on steam I bought it without a second thought because unlike most people I wanted to support the Crowbar Collective, because if anyone would take the time to read the early access description that you all apparently hate so much, It is stated that they are strapped for resources to continue working on it.

Do yourselves a favor and toss your irritating sense of entitlement aside. These people have been working toward this for 10 years and you're going to rub their face in ♥♥♥♥ because you like your mods free? Guess what. This isn't a mod anymore. Its a GAME.

- Faithful recreation of the source (no pun intended) material
- significant upgrades since it's days as a mod

Supporting this dedicated team of fans is well worth 20 dollars. Get over it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a remake of the well-appreciated Half Life, released about a decade earlier. Not just a graphical enhancement: pretty much the entire game is remastered, improved, upscaled performances and given an attractive look. A must-have, even for gamers who are unfamiliar with the series.

PROS:
+ Quite long gameplay
+ Crystal clear graphics
+ New sound effects
+ Awesome new interface, voice acting and weapon looks
+ Renewed level design
+ Trading cards

CONS:
- Ragdoll glitches after loading an area with corpses
- If you've played the original Half Life, you mostly know what's going to come
- Not all chapters from the original Half Life are included

If you love (alien) shooters, you'll love Black Mesa.

My rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is simply game of the year!
This is like the mod, but at the same time it isn't.
It is a masterpiece.
The textures, particles and lighting are very good, WAY better than the mod, and even the mod blew our minds.
The weapons are better, and more realistic.
For example: Remember the MP5 from the mod? It was mediocre, had low accuracy, and only shot in burst fire. Now, it has better accuracy, is fully automatic just like in real life, and it even has an awesome muzzle flare!

The graphics are amazing, it even compares to newer AAA games. Speaking of AAA games, this game beats most, if not, all of them!
May i remind you, that a team of modders developed this game?
How did they achieve this?
I'm quite surprised with the result of the standalone.
I just thought it would be the mod, with minor graphical impovements, among other things.
But no, It's a complete overhaul!
Well, how did they actually achieve this?
The answer is simple, dedication.
They dedicated 10 years of their life in order to develop such a great game.
They didn't ask for funding or anything, instead they used their own money.
Now that the game is mostly complete, I think we should do them a favor, and show them how much we appreciate their work and effort by purchasing this great game.
They deserve it...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok this one is going to be long:

This game has been on development for at least 8 years now I think and now we see it first release in steam, for those who do not know, this is a remake of Valve's legendary game ''Half Life'' released in 1998 in an updated Source engine.

What I like about it apart from the updated graphics obviously is how the developers carefully designed the game with interesting dialog and replaced some of the level design with fun mechanics, for example now you may want to stay to hear scientists conversations or do some physics puzzles.

It's really more advanced than the free version that was released in 2012, also, they included a multiplayer mode, it feels and plays like Half Life 1 and with the workshop support, we can expect to see pretty original things in the future.

In conclusion, it's an early access you want to get, even if you played Half Life before, this is a must get.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This total conversion overhaul will change the way you look at Half Life & it's modding community forever.
About The Game:
Black Mesa: Source or Black Mesa is a Half Life 2 Modification by very enthusiastic Half Life gamers. This modification is less of a modification and more of a total conversion overhaul. This game is a complete rehaul of the original Half Life with almost identical levels & gameplay, what makes this game so special that it's not like any of the other Half Life" remakes or Half Life: Source? Read on and find out!

The Story:
Black Mesa re-tells us an already very familiar story and amps up the anty by 10
date: with the solid plot line from the original Half Life with the glory of the Source Engine 2013 technology.\n\nYou are Gordon Freeman
recommended: a scientist hired to perform experiements in an underground research lab below Mexico desert. One day on your job you're tasked to insert a rare specimen from the planet "Xen" into a reactor machine which causes a resonance cascade that destroys the research facility
hoursPlayed: but the worst is yet to come. As you battle your way out of Black Mesa research facility through these strange alien creatures & a corrupt military task force hired to keep the Black Mesa incident a secret and stop anybody that is attempting to escape from the facility a strange man in a blue suit stalks Gordons every move
voteText:
who is this strange man & why is he here? It's up to you to unravel the mystery of this strange man.

The Gameplay:
The gameplay is the same familiar gameplay you would expect from any Source Engine game
helpfulPercent: it works identical to that of Half Life 2
votesHelpful: it's got solid gameplay
votesTotal: a beautifully & lovingly crafted modification that everyone expected "Half Life: Source" to be but were let down
votesFunny:
this is what we wanted from Valve but in the end we got it from a very tallented modding team.

The Verdict:
With a complete overhaul of Half Life you can expect things to be compaired to the original & with this total conversion you should expect to see a few significant changes to the original game
commentsCount: some new places to explore
column16: some alternate paths to take and some new faces to encounter
column17: although not identical to the original game it's very cannon to the original & nothing that is in the game feels out of place.\n\nThe gameplay is solid
column18: the guns feel like the original game & most importantly the game has 100% it's own content
column19: nothing is stock Half Life 2 assets
column20: even the enemies are recreated with rather noteable modifications
column21: they even went as far as to add their own voice actors to the game rather than using the voices from Half Life 2
column22: however in the Steam release you will hear that a few of the characters are using the original voice actors from Half Life 1 & 2
column23:
this is nice to have the noteable voices back in a game that is trying to be the Half Life game it does so well to replicate.

Do I Recommend This Game?:
Yes i certainly recommend this game
column24:
if you're still on the fence about paying for a modification then you can try the free version of this available here: http://www.blackmesasource.com/

If you DO NOT own the original Half Life you SHOULD own this! If you own the original Half Life you still SHOULD own this!

If after playing the free version you still don't feel like buying the game then there's nothing i can say to make you change your mind. However i will say that the money you spend here is going towards making these modders into an indie developer company which you should do as you can see they've really poured their heart and soul into this game which could easily be improved further."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although in early access only, Black Mesa is an excellent pastime for those who like reminiscing about the past and find it almost exquisite to play one of their favourite, classic FPS games in a greatly enhanced form. Yes, this is Half Life 1 but this time envisioned thanks to the amazing Source engine that made it possible for us to play the sequel along with the Left 4 Dead franchise.

Below are my pros and cons about this conversion:

+++ The game looks stunning! The creators did not just make a conversion but changed some of the environments. Added several items here and there to make severals rooms / hallways more realistic. Laboratories are now full of equipment; towards the end game we can really feel like being part of an ongoing war between the military and the invaders! Also, the faces of the characters look pretty cool - I assume this is a later iteration of the Source engine hence the better facial animations.
+++ Extra dialogue options: Especially true to the first level; just keep pressing E until you hear everything the scientists or guards have to say. And oh boy there's plenty they want to share with you!
+++ Achievements: Good ones, I have to admit! Remember the scientist in the toilet? Pass him the toilet paper!  Also, make sure you ruin the casserole in the microwave oven in the kitchen just like you did it in 1998. As the game is unfinished there are no story-related achievements at this point.

--- Sometimes enemies get stuck in one place. They just get frozen and do not react until you shoot them. It can be pretty annoying sometimes as tough battles can be completed too easily after several reloads.
--- This game is sure quite difficult! Even on normal difficulty level the soldiers can hit you from afar - this is pretty unfair and your kevlar (=HEV suit) gets depleted pretty fast almost all the time. Interestingly, the vortigaunts and the big soldier aliens are quite easy to get rid of (especially the big guys were annoying in the vanilla game). The battle on the dam with the helicopter is particularly challenging as the creators did not put enough cover there.
--- And the biggest issue of all: the game is unfinished. Once you jump into the portal to make your way to Xen the game ends. I initially played Black Mesa 2 or 3 years ago (downloaded from the creators' website - Steam release came only this year) and while many adjustments have been made since the 4 remaining chapters (chapter 15-18) are still missing.

Overall, this is a nicely done conversion. It ups the difficulty level so those getting used to today's casual games may find it quite challenging. While 10 euros are not much for the game (this is the lowered price - it gets discounted regularly) perhaps it's best to wait until Black Mesa is fully completed. However, if you are an avid fan of Gordon Freeman's journey just like myself grab it right away!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is probably the best game of all time.  That's not just nostalgia, it really is better than anything out there.

1. The game is a mix of combat and puzzles, something many games today still haven't figured out how to do.

2. The environment itself is a puzzle, in a way that feels extremely natural, with lots of interesting mechanics.

3. The story is both deeper and less intrusive than modern FPS games.  (No cut scenes!!!)  When was the last time you played as a physics PhD?

All in all, this is the kind of thing that got me into game development and computer science.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa made me thorughly enjoy Half-Life from start to finish, a feat I thought was impossible to achieve, because I hated HL1 with a passion.

This one plays great, looks great, and sounds even better.

Gameplay-wise it's pretty much what you'd expect from the original HL, with minor adjustments being made here and there to utilise the power and possibilities given by the Source engine and to make the game less frustrating. Not easier, just less frustrating. Some levels have been expanded, while others that felt like they were dragging on, were cut in size, especially the infamous rollercoaster ride. Oh, and the HECU soldiers were sent back to their boot camp and came back thrice as deadly. You'll be cursing like crazy whenever you overhear their radio chatter, because it means a tough fight lies ahead. The aleins are more deadly as well, especially Vortigaunts and Houndeyes. The latter posed next to no threat in the original game - here, if you don't kill them as soon as they appear, they'll mess you up. Bad. And they always hunt in pack of three or more.

In terms of graphics CC achieved something unimaginable - you're playing a Source game, and yet, when you look at it, it doesn't look like a Source game. Hundreds of new assets and textures, as well as new effects make it look like it was made in a completely different engine. The textures are crisp enough for you to be able to read what's written on the candy boxes inside vending machines and on computer screens. Everything has been modelled from a scratch, with the possible exception of dr. Kleiner's head. I hold a special place in my heart for the shotgun. The original looked and sounded like a toy, while this one feels like you're holding a gunmetal-black rabid beast that's only being held back by your trigger finger. It can obliterate everything short of a battle tank"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this originally when it first came out in 2012 and was a little skeptical about buying it this time around. Here's what I've noticed:
-Way better optimization.
-A lot of the areas have been redone and touched up.
-Achievements
-Multiplayer
-Steam Workshop

If you have not played Black Mesa yet then prepared for THE BEST recreation of one of THE BEST FPS GAMES OF ALL TIME! If you have never played Half Life before then shame on you because the game was years ahead of its time.

Black Mesa is jaw-dropping in every sense of the word(s). If you recall the level design in HL then you might remember a lot of detail back during those standards. Now imagine HL with todays detail that gamers expect. The level design here is mind numbingly good. Every single area is as unique as the last, the dynamic lighting is breath taking, and the models/textures are first rate.

Brief synopsis of the story here:
-Just another day at the Black Mesa facility. You are Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist from MIT arriving to work late. While at work, an experiment goes wrong and the next thing you know you have the find your way out of this madhouse full of aliens and marines. Experience where it all began with Black Mesa!

In short, this game is worth every penny of that $20. Can't wait to see how Xen looks when its finally done!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have always been left confused about how it took me 14 years after its initial release to discover Half-Life. It wasn't until 2012 that, by complete accident, I stumbled upon Half-Life after having bought it in a bundle. I tried it, and it changed my take on gaming forever. To this day, it is still, in my opinion, the most ambitious milestone in video game history, along with The Legend Of Zelda : Ocarina Of Time and BioShock. Like these two other games, it brought storytelling to a new dimension, which had only ever been reached by the greatest movie directors of the last century.

VALVe has my eternal respect for this major creation, but this respect is now shared with those who did what Gaben's Padawans couldn't do : make this legendary title live up to its sequel. The Crowbar Collective did a marvelous job, and they did it for free, until the creators of the franchise realized the power of this remake, and made the modders the ultimate gift : to sell their creation, as a reward for their outstanding achievement. Everything about this game is perfect, and gives a fresh look on this beloved franchise that has been left untouched since 2007 (if you leave out the two Portal games of course).

Buy it. You will not regret it. They're waiting for you. In the test chamberrrr....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Though its Early Access price might seem a little steep, Black Mesa offers some pretty great value: you've got the near-complete Half-Life experience, minus Xen levels to be added at a later date (as they're being significantly redesigned and improved from their lackluster 1998 incarnation), which is a solid 10+ hours. As Early Access adds new features to the game, expect to give it a few more playthroughs along the way (also, try to get the hidden hat achievement). Then you've also got the multiplayer, which is a great and very well constructed throwback to classic 1990s deathmatch. It's a lot of fun and though the map selection right now isn't too good, more levels are on the way.

As for the singleplayer: well, you've got a remake/reimagining of one of the greatest and most innovative games ever made. For one, it looks, feels and for all intents and purposes, plays better than the original, which sometimes suffered from issues inherent to games made in the late 90s. You've got a few clever surprises on the way that subvert player expectations in really cool ways, although they're few and far between. Overall, the story has been improved and in some ways expanded, a lot of new dialogue has been added, the environmental mise en scene" storytelling has been conserved if not improved. In a lot of respects it's simply a better experience - with all the amenities
date: details and mechanics of HL2 but the satisfying difficulty

votesTotal: almost half of On A Rail and a good third of Surface Tension). It just doesn't add anything to the experience and it stands out like a sore thumb on an experience that is otherwise light-years beyond anything AAA-supported studios put together these days (that includes Valve until they finally get around to making another singleplayer game)."

Good morning, and welcome to the Black Mesa Transit System. This automated train is provided for the security and convenience of the Black Mesa Research Facility personnel. The time is 8:47 A.M. Current topside temperature is 93 degrees with an estimated high of one hundred and five. The Black Mesa Compound is maintained at a pleasant 68 degrees at all times.

This train is inbound from Level 3 Dormitories to Sector C Test Labs and Control Facilities. If your intended destination is a high security area beyond Sector C, you will need to return to the Central Transit Hub in Area 9 and board a high security train. If you have not yet submitted your identity to the retinal clearance system, you must report to Black Mesa personnel for processing before you will be permitted into the high security branch of the transit system.

Due to the high toxicity of material routinely handled in the Black Mesa compound, no smoking, eating, or drinking are permitted within the Black Mesa Transit System. Please keep your limbs inside the train at all times. Do not attempt to open the doors until the train has come to a complete halt at the station platform. In the event of an emergency, passengers are to remain seated and await further instruction. If it is necessary to exit the train, disabled personnel should be evacuated first. Please, stay away from electrified rails, and proceed to an emergency station until assistance arrives.

A reminder that the Black Mesa Hazard Course decathlon will commence this evening at 1900 hours in the Level 3 facility. The semi-finals for high security personnel will be announced in a separate secure access transmission. Remember, more lives than your own may depend on your fitness.

Do you have a friend or relative who would make a valuable addition to the Black Mesa team? Immediate openings are available in the areas of Materials Handling" and "Low Clearance Security." Please contact Black Mesa personnel for further information. If you have an associate with a background in the areas of "Theoretical Physics

or other high-tech disciplines, please contact our Civilian Recruitment Division. The Black Mesa Research Facility is an equal-opportunity employer.

A reminder to all Black Mesa personnel. Regular radiation and biohazard screenings are a requirement of continued employment in the Black Mesa Research Facility. Missing a scheduled urinalysis or radiation check-up is grounds for immediate termination. If you feel you have been exposed to radioactive or other hazardous materials in the course of your duties, contact your radiation safety officer immediately. Work safe, work smart. Your future depends on it.

Now arriving at Sector C Test Labs and Control Facilities. Please stand back from the automated door and wait for the security officer to verify your identity. Before exiting the train, be sure to check your area for personal belongings. Thank you, and have a very safe, and productive day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Versão em português nos comentários)

It's Half-Life done better. Duh.

The amount and quality of the recreated content is amazing. Granted, there are many bugs, specially in regard to the artificial intelligence, and some of them do break the flow of the game, requiring a reload (to be fair, this happened just once, when I was trying to push a bit the limits of the linear gameplay). Other than that, it's great. Stuff's optimized for the level of graphic (and oh yes, it's graphic) detail, too: rarely I had any significant frame rate drop. Loading times are reasonable, I think, though some transitions are oddly placed.

If you liked the original, even if you haven't played it in a decade, it's pretty safe to get this whenever it goes on sale. Haven't completed it yet and don't care about multiplayer; still firmly recommended.

Few games have this much attention to detail. A fantastic game from start to finish. It's my first time playing Half-Life all over again.

Don't let the idiots whining about how there's already a free version discourage you; the changes here are for the better. All-new polish, a new engine, better voice acting, and so on. The addition of Deathmatch, plus the fact that it's tied into Steam, are so worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since this game is still in early access, I will replay the game again when it's completed. If things have changed for the better, I will give it a positive recommendation.
Half-Life and it's sequel are my favorite first person shooters. The franchise offers a unique experiance to the genre that has yet to be surpassed. I have replayed them hundreds of times!

Black Mesa offers an incredible re-imagining of Half-Life. Both in terms of it's gorgeous visuals and spectacular audio. The people who were responsible for it's detailed  environments, sound design and character development are a top notch level of talent! The Crowbar Collective has offered a stellar tribute to one of the greatest games of all  time. I wouldn't change anything about what the game offers in terms of its presentation.

What I would change is the most important part of any fps, the combat. The developers have decided against an exact replication of the original game. There certainly is nothing wrong with that choice. In fact I am overjoyed they decided to optimize some of Half-Life's more tedious and unnecessarily long chapters. While this has worked to improve the games pacing, it has hurt a crucial area of it's mechanics.

Black Mesa's redesign of the weapons makes fighting enemies far more aggravating. This is partially due to the larger number of enemies that have been included into the new ambush sections. Dealing with these new threats is particularly difficult because the reduced amounts of ammo that can be carried. Also, the damage in certain weapons (Specifically anything using explosives) has been reduced substantially compaired with the arsenal in Half-Life. Let me use the submachine-gun as a perfect example.

The SMG from Half-Life One:
Ammo: 50 round clip - 250 reserve - 10 grenades. Fairly accurate with a fair amount of recoil that was automatically compensated by Freeman.

As anyone knows the amount of ammo and number of guns was reduced significantly from half life one to its sequel. However whatever Valve took away they added something to replace it.

The SMG from Half-Life Two:
Ammo: 45 round clip - 225 reserve - 3 grenades. Very accurate and faster firing speed with a small amount of recoil that was automatically compensated by Freeman.

While we lost a small amount of bullets and large number of grenades, we gained a far
more accurate SMG with a higher rate of fire.

This is what the SMG looks like in Black Mesa:
Ammo: 30 round clip - 150 reserve - 3 grenades. Accurate in small bursts with a fair amount of recoil that is NOT compensated by Freeman. Grenades damage and area of effect was also reduced.

By these numbers the new SMG should be pin point accurate, no recoil at all and should fire even faster. The alternative being that the grenades should be at least 2 times more powerful than either of the Half-Life's.

While I could certainly go over the issues I have for each of the weapons, I won't.
Instead I will offer a quick list of changes that, in my opinion, would make for a better tribute.

1: Pistol - Half-Life 2 - Semi-Auto is love, Semi-Auto is life.
2: Magnum - Half-Life 2 - Suit Zoom + Accuracy = Head shot.
3: SMG - See Above... :-)
4: Shotgun - Half- Life 1 - Needs interruptible reload animation.
5: Crossbow - Remove the arch, faster reload, 25 ammo.
6: RPG - Please fix the laser guidance. Rockets bounce off enemies.
7: Explosives - Half-Life 1 level of devastation!
8: Exotic Energy Weapons - No issues.
9: Xen Weapons - All good.
10: Sprinting - Half-Life 1 - Let me sprint in ALL directions.

This is one of the times I wish the recommendation system had a mixed option.
I LOVE what has been done with the games graphics, sound and characters.
Not a big fan of the combat...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is, without a doubt, the best MOD in the Source engine development. I want to say it's 'one of the best', but it really does top off all HL2 MODs I have ever played. This review will cover the following: Price, and development.

Like most people, I like to get myself a good bargain. I never usually pay full price for games - especially games that were previously released for free. Would have I spent £14.99/$20 on a free game that became paid afterwards? Definitely not. Would have I paid that much to get quicker updates, receive a game I knew I was going to enjoy for longer than most modern games, have the game permanently registered onto my Steam account, and best of all, support the developers? ...I think this is already answered! (Not to mention any buyers are also supporting Valve in the process!)

With the many years of development put into it, starting with the same comical style you would expect in the start of Half-Life, continuing with the most beautiful model designs, textures, map layouts etc, and then ending with a brilliantly altered storyline - the developers really have outdone themselves! You really do feel like this is what Half-life should have been if it was made 20 years later as it still has that nice old style and clearly, as the game intends, it doesn't modernise itself too much! Whilst the storyline is based off HL1, you still get the nice treat and change now and then which makes you think 'this wasn't in HL1' - and that's what makes it even more enjoyable! You still get the HL1 experience, and you get the nice little Easter egg or slight path change to enjoy something else in the meantime!

Seriously, hats off to Crowbar Collective. They have worked to their fullest to provide us with this incredible MOD and no doubt they have put more effort into this game than most other modern developers have into current games that are far more popular!
voteText: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is the popular mod which aims to recreate (or re-imagine) the original Half-Life on the Source engine, providing much better graphics, mechanics and gameplay. The Crowbar Collective definitely achieved their goal, Black Mesa is nothing short of Phenomenal. Over the years it has won various awards, and even with a year or so of inactivity on their ModDB profile at the time, Black Mesa was still nominated to the top 10 mods of the year almost every time, and for a very good reason.

Black Mesa is very true to the original Half-Life in terms of level design, gameplay and difficulty, but at the same time it feels familar yet different, it is not a direct carbon copy. The chapter Questionable Ethics and Lambda Core are good examples of this. Some maps and areas are diferent or cut somewhat shorter such as On a Rail and Surface Tension which are both missing some sections found in the original game, this is the only real drawback, but it delivers in almost ever other aspect. All of the weapons you use in the original game make a return too, and while they now have a more limited aummunition capacity, they look excellent and are fun to use.
On top of the graphical overhaul, Black Mesa delivers in terms of depth too, some excellent voiceacting and dialog really help add to the imersive atmosphere and explaining the story and situation further, not to mention the excellent quality of the maps making the game more atmospheric than it has ever been before.

Now that Black Mesa is available on Steam to purchase as a standalone game, I couldn't recommend it more. The gameplay is solid and the game itself is flawlessly beautiful. The addition of achievements, the Steam Workshop and automatic updates add much more to make Black Mesa even better and reliable. Valve themselves couldn't have done a better job on this, definitely worth the asking price.

Do note that Black Mesa is still under development, hence Early Access"
date: so the Xen portion of the game currently doesn't exist."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Almost everything that made Half-Life the classic it is today, and the few things missing are greatly overshadowed by everything else which is improved. You've got much better graphics, better sounds, really awesome reskinned guns, and the same level layout we all remember and love.*

*A few areas have been slightly redesigned and some long, drawn out areas have been shortened seamlessly. Ultimately not a big deal to me, especially since there's workshop mods you can download that restore the cut areas.

The main thing I didn't like was the new voice acting. It's all right, I just prefer the original. I also prefer the music of the original but the new music here is good too.

It should be noted that currently the game only goes up to the portal that sends you to Xen; Xen will be finished at a later date and added to the game for free (of course). What is here is still many hours of fun with the promise of more to come! Also there's multiplayer but I didn't mess with that.

So is this game worth $20? It's a complete reimagining of Half-Life, FAR more than a simple graphics mod. Therefore yes I feel it's worth it, especially if you're a huge fan of the Half-Life series and want more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Single Player:



Story spoiler:
It's Half-Life 1 how do you not know the story? Seriously? Fine. The story takes place at the Black Mesa Research Facility in New Mexico. You play as a theoretical physicist named Gordon Freeman". You are heading off to your normal day of work and to nobody's surprise everything goes to hell. You are then sent throughout the Black Mesa Research Facility against both the U.S. Military and aliens alike
date: starting your adventure in the Sector C research labs
recommended: making your way through the offices of Black Mesa
hoursPlayed: the railway transits
voteText: hell that is known as the surface
helpfulPercent: and then the lambda complex. (To be Continued: Xen.) The game is basically one long "Get from Point A to Point B" with a bunch of puzzles
votesHelpful: confusing level design (To new players)
votesTotal: and some small boss battles along the way. But with the twist of the design forcing you to plot how you will play the game through
votesFunny: make you conserve your ammunition
commentsCount:
and at some points question your mental sanity and wonder how the hell you're supposed to get through that room with 3 health and no armour left at all.



Level Design:

Can you really count "Level Design" since it's a remake? Damn straight you can. A lot of small and large changes were made to the game's levels. Even adding some new areas to the game. Some of the more noticeable changes are the scenery during the introductory tram ride
column16: sector C laboratories
column17:
and the surface areas. It's just enough of a difference to keep the game going without making it feel like you're playing something that isn't Half-Life 1.

Downside in the level design: The "Vent maze" and the "Tram maze" were cut from the Steam version of the game as the developers said they don't feel they were made to their standards. A user has re-uploaded them from the mod version to work compatibly with the game on the Steam Workshop.(On a Rail Link) (We've got Hostiles Link)


Cutscenes:

The game has been given a much more dramatic feel with more voice actors
column18: facial generation
column19: and quite a few added little cutscenes and dialogue. For example in Half-Life 1: "What the hell are you still doing here? Get topside I hear troops are coming to rescue us." Almost every guard or hiding scientist has their little story to share when you find them. All the existing cutscenes in the game have been overhauled amazingly well
column20:
one of my favourite being the "Tentacle Scene" in the rocket firing chamber. which has seen some rather nice improvement in visuals and sounds from the mod version. Also the new voices for the HECU soldiers in the Steam version are a ton better than the original mod version's in my opinion.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zNqVc5Nq8_k


Gameplay:

The game itself plays relatively similar to Half-Life 1 with added physics
column21: but controls and moves as if it were Half-Life 2. You have the option in the "Black Mesa" section of the options menu to make your character always run
column22: more like Half-Life 1 was. Holding sprint in either mode will make the player run significantly faster and play an animation on all weapons other than the crossbow and the satchel charge. The weapons all function the same. Satchels explode on command
column23:
grenades have their same insane movement influence in gravity.


Soundtrack:

Joel Nielson did an amazing job. Damn near perfect. (My personal favourite song being the first On a Rail segment) The soundtrack seems to fit amazing with the ambiance and progression of the game and it's story. The combat music is some of the better sides (Questionable Ethics #1 being an exceptional example) and fits very well into the Half-Life feel of the game. I truly imagine this mod would not have made it as far without his works added to the game.


Other:

The visuals
column25: and AI for the game have been extremely improved upon. (AKA HECU and scientists no longer run into grenades.) The visuals to the game are extreme. Quality you'd expect from an actual game studio. Albeit limited due to the source engine. The sound design is superb
column26: meant for modern systems with surround sound providing an extremely immersive experience.\n\nA few smaller new features were added to Black Mesa
column27:
such as an auto-crouch jump (This can be turned off from the "Black Mesa" section of the options menu). Which I can only feel was added solely because of DSP.


Multiplayer:

Note: The multiplayer is incomplete as of the current time this review was written and has some changes planned to be made. I will keep this section bound to core elements only.

Gameplay:

The game in multiplayer plays near parallel to Half-Life: Deathmatch's. And yes
column28: crossbow bolts explode again. The multiplayer maps are being remade and modified to Black Mesa's play style and completely overhauled in visuals. It feels essentially like Half-Life Deathmatch but with an HD remake overlayed over it
column29:
but with changes in all the right places.


Levels: (?)

The multiplayer maps have to be downloaded from the Steam Workshop. If I have to guess this is so the developers can easily update a map without having to release an update for the entire game. As of the current time there are the following maps available from play officially from the BMS team: "dm_rocketfire
column35:
and dm_power". Adding up to seven maps currently.



A list of the good
column36:
and the bad:

Good:

- Complete Overhaul. Not much more needs to be said there.

- Balanced and fun to play multiplayer which will have more features in future updates

- Just holy hell that soundtrack.

- Plenty of little Easter eggs
column38:
and references to find everywhere.

- More improvements than the free mod version

Bad:

- The AI can still show it's typical for the source engine at times (Several times I've walked up to HECU Soldiers and they did not do anything but stare at me with their gun practically in my throat.)

- Being on Source
column39: you can expect both good physics
column40: but at the same time physics that will break at a moments notice and likely injure or damage the player.\n\n- Just holy hell
column41: the human assassins will swarm the player and just spray away with their guns
column42:
making it extremely difficult to kill them without explosives or wild gunfire before dying. (You have about 5-10 seconds on the medium difficulty before they kill you.)


My "Overall" rating would be ultimately a  9.4 out of 10.

The game itself is very balanced in both singleplayer and multiplayer aspects
column43: the game plays and runs fluently. I've got no real complains outside the human assassin's tendency to swarm the player."

reviewText:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning: This review contains spoilers. Read at your own risk.

I can safely say, that this is one of the best video game remakes that i have ever gotten to experience in my life. It's the treatment Half-Life, one of the best FPS games ever developed, deserved.

Black Mesa, while having a special touch to itself, still reminds you of Half-Life when you play it.

Story: The story is the same as the original Half-Life. You play as the scientist Gordon Freeman, and have to escape from the Black Mesa Research facility after an experiment goes horribly wrong. On your way out, you will encounter hostile aliens such as Vortigaunts, who are invading the facility and killing everyone they see. Later in the game you will also have to fight against human soldiers who have been sent in to clean up" the situation. The game's story is just as refreshing as the original game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played Half-Life back when it was new, high graphic FPS games were in their diapers and the few online games were done on a dial-up connection.  Black Mesa is basically Half-Life with a huge facelift.  I knew I would recommend this game before playing it because I'm a veteran of the original Half-Life games.  If you're an avid player of first person shooters you owe it to yourself to play Black Mesa (or the original HL).  This game was groundbreaking back when it was new.  Just like playing Super Mario is my cornerstone of platformer games, Half-Life is my cornerstone of first person shooters/adventure games.  Black Mesa has huge graphical improvements and keeps the same epic story of Gordon Freeman.  If you like sci-fi shooters with a great adventure or you want to spark up some Half-Life nostalgia, play Black Mesa!

Pros
- Just like Half-Life but an awesome remake.
- Graphics.
- Adventure.
- Achievements, cards and other stuff available from Steam.
- Reminds me of the days Valve still made games.
- A classic PC first person shooter you must have.

Cons
- Valve is too busy making money from Steam to care about making more games like this!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing Half-Life remake, the developers did an extraordinary job and deserve to have their work appreciated.  It really shows how big of a fan the developers are of the Half-Life series. I have never seen a group of people put so much effort into a free mod that is being turned into a work of art and something that will be recognized world wide as a master piece.  With all that said, the multiplayer needs a ton of work:
1) The game crashes often
2) Very poor performance (studdering, low framerate, ladders are very laggy and netcode needs optimization)
3) The bunny bhop doesn't work well
4) The crossbow zoom isn't instant, can't quick zoom
5) Crossbow bolts aren't hitscan like HL1DM or Adrenaline gamer
6) The gauss charges slower than HL/AG
7) The gauss no longer does splash damage on corner wall shots
8) The gauss doesn't penetrate walls effectively and do splash damage behind
9) Suit chargers are not 30 points anymore (75 now) and charge way too quickly for competitive play
10) Spawning takes up to 7 seconds or more and the camera follows the fragger.  HL/AG is instant respawn and HL2DM is 4 seconds.  This isn't ideal for competitive play especially when playing 2v2's and 3v3's.

I really hope the developers keep these things in mind and implement them as the game gets developed.  As of right now, the game is no where near ready for competitive play (weapon and gameplay wise).  Alot of old HL1DM and Adrenaline gamer players that quit in late 2005 would only come back if these major unique gameplay features are implemented.  The days of fast paced arena deathmatch games of the late 90's and early 00's are long gone but I hope this game gives that genre one last breath.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: Rocket launcher, MP5, glock, .357, all rendered inert by the MACHINE GUN CROWBAR. Thanks HEV suit for adding the new rapid-fire crowbar functionality!

10/10 would crowbar insanely fast again.


Honestly, as much as I want to beat the crap out of this mod for charging $20 when I ratted on Aperture Tag for costing $7, I can't. By comparison, this is actually worth your money. Where Aperture Tag was a literal mod that required a base game and only provided a whopping 3 hours of gameplay with an innovative but forgettable gameplay design, this comes with roughly double to triple that in single player gameplay (with more being added later), multiplayer, and it's entirely standalone.

The devs of this have worked their rear ends off to get this to where it is, with 8 years of work or so now. I have to praise every moment of it too, as while a lot of it is due to it simply being Half Life, this is also infinetly more enjoyable as Half Life has started to age a bit. The music and sound design is absolutely superb, the graphics are some of the best the source engine has to offer, and the atmosphere and gameplay have been massively improved, not taken away from, by this mod. This is not a simple graphical upgrade, but rather a full redesign of the entire game from the ground up. That means redesigned levels, movement, AI, etc. with all of it being extremely well made. It helps to make the entire game far more immersive, and it ends making me wish there was more - I know Xen is on the way, but that's not enough. The design of this mod is so great, it makes me want more of EVERYTHING. WHERE IS HALF LIFE 3, GABEN?

As it stands, I haven't touched the multiplayer yet, but I have run through the single player. I felt scared, alone, excited, surprised, and overall felt immersed far more into this than I ever could into the 1998 Half Life. Multiplayer is effectivelly a rehash of the original deathmatch, but now with workshop support and various other improvements. I imagine it would add many, MANY hours onto an already fantastic game, easily doubling or tripling what you can already get.

It's honestly hard to stop gushing and face facts, but there are some. This game has its' issues. I've encountered issues with enemies spawning in as blank, unanimated corpses that do nothing, issues with the AI getting permanently stuck on something, issues with clipping my view through stuff, and issues with sound effects overlapping each other to the point of my headset giving up and just delivering a blank rather than actual sound. And, admittedly, a lot of the gush is made possible simply because this is based on the fantastic Half Life. Were it not for that, I cannot say if it would be as good as it is.

However, I would indeed say buy this. You will not only get your money's worth, but you will be supporting devs who have been caring for this project for MANY years now, as well as simple convinience of things like auto-updating and such when new content and fixes come out. I recommend this easily.

BUY THIS!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI never played the original HL, but I had played all the games from HL2 up and I loved them. The improved mechanics and AI make the game far more challenging, and the overall visual effect is stunning. I give this game a huge recommend to those who have never played HL1 and a high recommendation for those who have.

It's Black Mesa. Enough said. Weapons have been redone, with many new models, and the pistol and crowbar feeling a lot slicker. The engine is also newer compared to the mod, and you may notice many subtle tweaks that've happened since release. There's also the multiplayer, and if you've played Half-Life's, you'll find it familiar.

It's a high-quality work of passion that's been in development for many years, and if you enjoyed the mod or the original Half-Life this is well worth a purchase. The mod is, of course, still available for free, as is the excellent soundtrack.

Xen levels are still yet to be released.
