reviewText:
Early Access Review

If Black Mesa still was a usual mod, I'd give it as many positive screams as possible, and would be running with it around screaming on every corner how awesome it is. Basically, at the time I more or less did it, when original mod came out. But this is not a mod. This is a game that's sold for a price. This is a PRODUCT. Even more so, this is now just another HD remake, like Homeworld Remastered, Majesty Gold HD or Silent Hill 2 HD. And I am evaluating it exactly this way.

Half Life - the original game - was nearly flawless in terms of level design. Environments were expressive, but never restrictive, all levels differed from one another, and the game was overall one whole innovation. But this is not 1998, it is 2015. How does this remake hold up?

Let's start with some positives. Environments are stunningly great. Details on all models and in all location are epic - you can see there was a lot of attention put into the game. Same goes to new models, like bullsquids, military guys, alien grunts, black ops, helicopters and so on. All areas look more or less realistic. Huge machinery is simply breathtakingly awesome.

All weapons are back as well, and they all are quite pleasant to use.

Story wise nothing has changed - it is the same old Half-Life with some lore-friendly elements added from Half-Life 2, like Dr. Vance and Dr, Kleiner.

Most of the levels follow the original with added level of details like additional doors to mimic open environments. Some areas changed though - especially Surface Tension level, which got a lot bigger, and On The Rail, getting MUCH smaller.

Music came out to be great and atmospheric, an actual improvement over original soundtrack, I must admit.

But what's bad? Level design and atmosphere - this is where problems start to pop up. For starters, some later levels were showing alien infestation spreading in the area - weird fungus, strange surfaces, odd looking formations; in this game there are THREE areas which at least resemble alien infested zones that were in the original, and they both seem soooo much out of place because the rest is absent.

In Half-Life there were areas where you needed to get help from guards and scientists - now there is only one area where you REQUIRE them. Also there is zero tension between Freeman and military now. Famous Forget about Freeman!" line is now absolutely out of place - mostly thanks to super-cut On the Rail level

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of Half-Life at all, chances are you'll probably also thoroughly enjoy Black Mesa. It combines the best of both Half-Life and Half-Life², into one very solid game, with the technology of the Source engine. If you played the mod version that was released about 3 years ago, you will be very surprised to see that the standalone version is almost an entirely different game, attributed to the amount of upgrades and polishing that has been done to the single-player campaign. Most of the weapons have new models, and all of them have completely new animations. The MP5, Hand Grenades and explosive Satchel Charges have received some gameplay improvements, with the MP5 now being full auto, rather than 3-round-burst. Hand Grenades and Satchel Charges can now be thrown much farther than in the previous version, and you can now cook grenades to have them detonate sooner after being thrown. Voice acting in this version is top-notch, with a lot of lines being re-done to do a better job at making the characters seem more like real people.

The new multiplayer mode of the game is really really fun, and it is very similar to the multiplayer component of the original Half-Life, although it currently seems to almost lack the ability to bunny-hop. Weapon balance seems to be pretty good, although in my opinion, the Tau Cannon's secondary fire should need to be charged for a longer period of time to be a one-shot kill.

Now for the big question... is the game currently worth it? That's a decision that I can't make for you. If you're a huge fan of Half-Life and you really think you'll enjoy what the game currently has to offer, then, by all means purchase the game. I see the $20 price tag as more of a donation to the developers than an actual price for the game itself. The Crowbar Collective has been working on Black Mesa for about 10 years at this point, and now is the best time for the community to show even more appreciation for their work. Black Mesa is outstanding, and it's only going to get better from here on out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, fist of all, i´m a big fan of the Half-Life series and in my opinion HL1 was better than the second one or the episodes. Sure, graphics, game-play or the engine: No need to argue,  Half-Life2 + episodes win these points. For me personally, the bigger impact (mainly the  atmosphere), had the first part. So, just keep in mind, this review is a pretty subjective one.

I was pretty happy, when I saw the first few screenshots and facts, from the Black Mesa Project. Then, they released the free modification and it was overwhelming. I saw so much love for details, while playing. It felt like the good old classic, but in a fresh and modern environment. It´s also not a simple 1:1 remake, they also brought in some little changes and ideas, but never destroying the atmosphere of the original. Sure, the current Source-engine is not state-of-the-art anymore, but can still be impressing, if you ask me.

If you like the first Half-Life, this modification is simply a must-play!

I remembering the heated debate, when Valve thought about an option to pay for mods, some weeks ago. I understand most of the points of both sides, but the day they were offering Black Mesa-Early Access on steam-store, there was no alternative for me: Shut the hell up and take my fu&%$& money. :-)

If you don´t want to pay for it/early access, it´s okay. If you own a game that uses the source engine, you still can download and play the free modification. The final xen-part is missing in both versions. Its just, I wanted to reward their great work, since the day I played the free modification. And now I did..

As I said above: It´s  going to be a pretty personal review. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before the pros and cons,you need to know that I'm the kind of gamer that pays attention to graphics and animation quality.I simply can't ignore them because this is the 21st century for God's sake.I'm also not a fan of old games.I only play them again for nostalgia.Black Mesa,on the other hand,surprises me.The nostalgic feeling and the modern feel of the game is very balanced for me and I admit that I like this game even though this is based on an old game.This game is the old Half Life modded with way much better graphics.Don't expect some epic gameplay like Crysis's or CoD's or Battlefield's.They're trying to keep the classics feel alive.
Pros :
+ Great graphics,but not epic (remember,it's a mod)
+ Classic half life gameplay.The nostalgic feeling is the only reason why I bought this game.
+ Steam workshop available with cool mods from the community
+ Haven't tried the multiplayer,but I saw a lot of people is having fun with it
+ Puzzle combined with horror and shooting action.Just like the old half life
+ If you played the old half life,you'll be very satisfied with this game.The improvements are drastic and amazing.
+ Challenging gameplay (single player)

Cons :
- The graphics when you're inside the building is great.But,when I was playing the level on the surface,I realized that I shouldn't expected much graphical improvement from a mod of an old game.
- Almost zero soundtrack.I understand they're trying to keep the classics feel but the thrilling part of the game is a failure due to lack of creepy soundtrack.There's no 'feel' along the gameplay without proper soundtrack.
- Boring single player story.Not enough plot twists to 'wow' me.The story is really monotone. I understand it's Half Life, the multiple award winning game etc etc but that won't stop me from criticizing it
- Crude animations

Overall,this is a meh game. The pros and the cons is balanced for me and I got bored to play this game after a couple of hours. I meant no offense for the half life fans. I know that they're trying to revive an old game by combining it with the 21st century gaming technology but I do think they need to do more to attract more people than just half life fans and 20 year old guys trying to replay their childhood memories.Of course,not all of the current players are either of them and I don't know they are successful statistically or not. I would still recommend this game even if you are not a half life fan. It's still worth the price.

A professional re-envisioning of where Half Life all started - Black Mesa have worked on all aspects of the game from graphics to AI and created something of a masterpiece in repro-Mods that still remains true to the original, and has quirky elements and a level of small detail that you rarely find in other titles.
If you play Half Life for tactics - this is the game for you. If you play to throw inanimate objects at scientists to provoke a response, this is the game for you. If you play to hit giant fish with a crowbar at a feverish rate, well... still the game for you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok...
First things first: I've played Half-Life on my PS2 and also finished the Decay game path (with Dr. Cross and Dr. Green) to 100% for unlocking the secret Vortigaunt mission.
When I bought Half-Life 2 I got a free copy of Half-Life: Source too which I played again on PC.
So I know the older versions very well...

And I really have to say that this remake is how remakes should be done: New graphics, old gameplay.
Like using the slogan: Never change a running system.

I've also played the mod in 2012 and I cannot see anything bad in this EA title, except that you're able to get a free copy of this game as well but just as a Source-Mod. Probably without some features which are only available in the retail version.
Example: There seems to be also a multiplayer but I am not that interested in it yet.
However, the campaign is as good as it was in the year 1998. Just with better graphics, a few additions but also a few reductions.
Nothing which matters in such a bad way to give this game bad credit.

I don't know why there are people who complain about that remake, but they probably overestimate their own opinion.
As for an EA game it works flawless and I am looking forward to further content arriving (especially the final release of Xen).
If people want to have a similar experience without the need to pay they should stick with the mod and calm down.



Ok...
Das Wichtigste zuerst: Ich habe Half-Life damals auf meiner PS2 gespielt und ebenfalls die Decay-Missionen zu 100% abgeschlossen, um die geheime Vortigaunt-Mission freizuschalten.
Danach kaufte ich mir Half-Life 2 für PC und in dem Paket war ebenfalls eine Gratiskopie von Half-Life: Source enthalten, was ich ebenfalls wieder spielte.
Also kenne ich die alten Versionen sehr gut...

Und ich kann nur sagen, dass man Remakes genauso machen sollte: Neue Grafik, altes Gameplay.
Ganz nach dem Motto: Ändere niemals ein funktionierendes System.

Zuvor spielte ich die Mod anno 2012 und ich kann nichts Schlechtes an diesem EA-Titel erkennen, außer, dass man ebenfalls in der Lage ist das Spiel gratis eben als Source-Mod zu erhalten. Selbstverständlich fehlen einige Features der Verkaufsversion.
Beispiel: Es gibt auch einen Multiplayer, an dem ich jetzt aber nicht so interessiert bin.
Wie auch immer, die Kampagne ist genausogut wie damals 1998 nur eben mit besserer Grafik und einigen Erweiterungen, aber auch Einsparungen.
Nichts was grob ins Gewicht fallen würde.

Ich weiß nicht warum manche Spieler sich so sehr über dieses Remake aufregen, aber wahrscheinlich überschätzen sie nur ihre eigene Meinung.
Für ein Early Access-Spiel funktioniert es makellos und ich freue mich auf die kommenden Inhalte (speziell auf den vollständigen Release der Xen-Episoden).
Wenn Leute eine ähnliche Erfahrung machen möchte, ohne etwas dafür zu zahlen sollen sie bei der Mod bleiben und sich beruhigen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa brings you back to the Half-Life 1 universe to a completely new, refined state.
Crowbar collective has worked on the game for so long, it's unimaginable.

When I say it is all brought to refined state I mean everything.
The models, the textures, the sounds, the gameplay, everything you can think of.
The models are detailed to smallest inches, especially the viewmodels. They are beautiful, I mean it.
The textures are all so high-res it is stunning. The normal maps applied especially.
The sounds is what has a very important impact in the game, without them the game wouldn't be so sweet!
I can continue on, but I'd have to include the level design, animations, everything.

Worth the money?
If you love the work of Crowbar Collective - hell it is. To confirm whether you like it or not you should play the mod they released 3 years ago, if you're unaware, of course.

So, just now I played the multiplayer.
Guys, its a massacre. But its a hilarious massacre.
You would never know what would happen if you threw those tiny red green-eyed bugs all over the map.
:D
...
:DDD
...
>:DDDD

There is too much to say, I would almost give everything 10/10, but there are a few cons.

The one I found the most unsettling is the engine does not support LDR (low dynamic range) and only supports HDR. This isn't the game's fault, it's the engine that does not allow that, sadly. This has quite the massive effect on the performance of low-end PC's, while at the same time it still keeps the good graphics however.

But all in all my score:
Models 9/10
Texutres 10/10
Sounds 9/10
Level design 10/10
Particle effects 10/10
Multiplayer 8/10 (there are things to discuss, but as of early access it's what it is).

Overall: 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

while it is a good remake/Re-imagining i cant help but notice they missed on alot design wise and threw away some of the most iconic things that made half-life what it is.

Pros

- an updated look at a world we all loved.
- new HD models for everything.
- looks pretty.
- Skins and Voice packs from the community help with the lack of good content.
- Amazing Music Score

Cons

- Animation screw ups (grunts hold MP5 weirdly, Barneys have issue drawing their weapons)

- Grunt Design Fails (No iconic ski-mask grunts, no green lenses for gas mask grunts, some grunts dont have gloves and just look silly, no HEV Vest or backpacks for grunts.)

- 3D model scaling is just awful, World model for shotgun looks goofy and small, RPG grunt kills himself with oversized rpg when ever he fires.

- Voice Acting (while security and scientist are amazing the grunts hit rock bottom with just major fail. No iconic radio chatter sadly and are just forgettable, You are better off downloading the classic or Opposing Force grunts voices than what is given here.)

- Skins and voice packs required to make up for the design fails of the dev team.

- Having to rely alot on mod community for aesthetic fixes.

Like i stated above this game is good but misses alot of what made HL what it is but also added some new flavor in the mix with an awesome Music Score and level design its just sad they dropped the ball on the most iconic things in the HL world (Grunts). Now personally i dont think it worth the 20 bucks since i needed to download skins and voices just to re-immersed myself in this updated world but to each its own.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am about 4 hours into the game (close to beating the singleplayer) and I am absolutely in love with this recreation of Half-life. The level designs are breath taking compared to the level design of the original, though there were some parts that made me rage a little bit, but those were just hard sections no bugs or anything. Graphics look downright beautiful, playing on a 144Hz monitor, turning all of the settings to the max including AA is a very exhilarating experience. Gameplay wise there are levels that are even harder than the singleplayer of the original half-life, I don't want to spoil them to the players that are going to play this game in the near future, I'm just letting you guys take note that this game is quite a challenge. I will say that the MP5 is a lot more accurate than the MP5/M16 in the original half-life so that's less of a challenge on that part of the game. A huge majority of the sound effects are brand new and not from the original Half-life, the sound effects do sound great when compared to the graphics(which are really well made from the Source engine.) Overall this is a very brilliant recreation of the insta-classic Half-life, If you're even on the slightest side of being a Half-life fan then i would highly recommend playing this game, you won't be disappointed. If you're a huge Half-life fan like i personally am, just buy the game without even thinking about it. really enjoying this so far and I can't wait until the developers are finished with the Xen related chapters. I wish the best of luck to the developers working on the Xen related chapters of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Half-Life has been my absolute favouritest single player game ever since it came out, so I was naturally excited when I heard Black Mesa was being developed.  This January I decided to play through it from start to finish, and I was both positively and negatively surprised.

Starting with the good parts: obviously, the graphics have been improved a lot.  At times the game is even beautiful to look at.  I found the level design quite nice while still staying close to that of the original.  I can't say which ones I liked more, but some of the puzzles" had been slightly altered compared to HL1; mostly they had a more HL2-ey feel to them.  The sound track is absolutely phenomenal.

As for the bad parts..  The game is still really buggy.  Two or three of the weapons didn't seem to be working correctly -- one of them was bad enough that it was completely unusable in the game thanks to its unreliability
date: and even caused a couple of crashes until I figured out how to avoid them.  The scopes in the revolver and the crossbow zoom in and out so slowly that you'll simply die before you get a chance to adjust your aim
recommended: and sometimes they just do something completely wacko.  There doesn't seem to be a way to walk without crouching if "Always Run" is on.  The AI sometimes completely stops working (e.g. Vortigaunts just staring at you)
hoursPlayed: and even when it is working
voteText: it's sometimes bad enough that it can be abused for cheap kills (for example
helpfulPercent: an Alien Grunt can be killed at melee range with the SMG without taking any damage).  The list goes on and on and on.\n\nAside from all the bugs
votesHelpful: the number of additional revolver magazines you're allowed to carry was brought down from five to two
votesTotal: which I thought really hurt my ability to clear bunkers stationed at open or semi-open areas
votesFunny: especially since there didn't seem to be a lot of hand grenades available.  A similar treatment was given to crossbows: you're only allowed to carry around two extra magazines (down from nine)
commentsCount: and gravity now affects your bolts
column16: which makes long-distance shots a lot more difficult.  Perhaps a change here was in order compared to the original
column17: but I found myself with practically no means to clear bunkers several times over the course of the game.  The Glock is still for some reason really accurate at long distances
column18: so by repeatedly peeking from behind a wall I could kill soldiers from long distances without taking too much damage.  I'm simultaneously both sad that that worked as well as it did
column19: and that it was necessary due to poor balancing of the other long range weapons.\n\nAt times I thought the level design had not been tested well enough.  Several times when I was lost I managed to find my way into a dead end from which I could not get back (up
column20: usually).  I'm generally terrible at knowing where to go in games
column21: but it's even worse if there's absolutely no way to get back to the "intended" route
column22: short of loading an earlier save.  But I'm not sure whether these are problems specific to Black Mesa
column23: or if the original game had the same shortcomings as well.\n\nThe way the (currently) final boss in the game played out was really boring.  This coupled with the fact that there's no Xen at all
column24: I was really disappointed in the end.\n\nAll in all
column26: but I'd wait a few more months for the bugs to be fixed and Xen to be added
column27: and maybe pick the game up from the Summer Sales.  If you're a fan of the original Half-Life
column28: it's still a great way to re-live the old game in a (very) slightly different package.  If you didn't get to enjoy the original Half-Life (or you're just not feeling nostalgic)
column29: I'd suggest looking at Half-Life 2 instead."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright! So with me completeing the game, I can now give my thoughts about the game, But I'll just do pro's and con's.

PROS:-The game almost feels like it was made by valve, so a fantastic job to 'Crowbar Collective'!
-The atmosphere and environment of the game is absolutely stunning and perfect!
-They removed some of the parts of the original Half-life that was very annoying to get through, which is great!
-The sounds, and the visuals is top-notch!
-This is a very good game to start on if you are interested in playing the Half-life series!
-With 16 hours of gamplay, I was not at one point bored or uninterested in the current situation of the game.

CONS:-The voice acting was good, but it's like every scientist I would walk to, they all had the same voice actor, which was just a bit odd at times. Same for the security guards/police. Hearing the same voices kind of made the game feel repititive.
-The levels where you go to the alien's planet is completely removed/not added to the game, resulting in entering the teleporter, it ends the game. I think its kind of unacceptable for them to take this long to develop those final levels, but when they are finished, they better be good!

So thats the pros and cons of the game. I'll be honest, after beating Black Mesa, the old love I had for Half-life had came back. Its a shame that Half-Life 3 to this day still isn't even confirmed. Either way though, Black Mesa remasters Half-Life in just the right way, which my final score will be:

8/10 (It could be a 9/10 if the Xen levels could come sooner)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The paid Early Access version so far is a disappointment to me compared to the free mod.

First of all there are numerous bugs.
Vortigaunts often stay completely motionless and frozen, so you can kill them easily.
NPC bodies are twitching around randomly. Physics objects are often stuck in the floor or also twitching around.
Very often there is a 'Node graph out of date. Rebuilding.. message when you start a new map.
I can remember none of these things in the free mod and they ruin the immersion I felt with the free mod.

Second:
The free mod also had some funny textures scattered around the first level
date: which they removed. There are many places in many maps in the new version that seem reachable
recommended: but are not reachable either due to invisible walls or unimplemented physics for ladders. In the current state playing the paid version has been a worse experience than playing the free mod and the Xen chapters are not even added yet and this might still take a very long time.\n\nSo currently in this alpha state I wouldn't recommend spending $20 on this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a modern remake of Half-Life, which started out as an ambitious mod and has been released as a fully fledged, standalone game, Currently in Early Access the developers have committed to continued support and bringing the final Xen levels that were missing from the mod. As it is set before Half-Life 2, Black Mesa follows the events that occurred to bring the Combine to Earth in the second game. It is part horror and part full blown action.

Black Mesa, as a mod, always had a rough ride in getting over the final hurdle. Changes in engine, team members, and the sheer pace in which modern games have evolved makes it an accomplishment that the mod was released and for free. They have now released their game on Steam and with a deathmatch component which is hoping to bring new players a small slice of what Half-Life Deathmatch was like. The retail version is running on a hybrid of Source engines so contains changes that aren't backwards compatible with the mod version. Most of the changes are subtle improvements in lighting, more stability and bugfixes, but also integration with Steamworks. Already there are new DM maps and mods for Black Mesa in the Steam Workshop which add to the experience.

Black Mesa is pretty comparible to other retail games. It has a good level of polish overall but has a few odd blemishes along the way. I think it is safe to say the Black Mesa, as the title suggests, is about the facility. The level of detail and focus put on the actual environment is very impressive. The machinery and laboritories are the best elements of the game. There is some equipment which is expertly modeled. When you see it in motion with the sound effects it is quite a sight. Overall the sound design is good, voice acting is well done with improvements to the HECU (marines) but there are some voices that are out of place. In some places Black Mesa also feels deathly quiet or slightly muffled with only an air con unit humming or a distant thumping. In Half-Life, sound was used to announce danger, so the HECU would be overly loud on their radios or the Vortigaunts would be gargling away. Yes, in Half-Life it was over the top but it made the game feel punchy. In places Black Mesa has no impact and I think it is down to the sound.

The AI have been reworked since the mod, so no more HECU soldiers sniping you with aimbot machine guns, and the aliens attacks have a bit more delay to them. However the developers seemed to have dialed them down too much to the point where the soldiers are almost pacifistic at times. They seemed to be scripted to hold back or huddle up. Some encounters I've seen them run back and forth between a rock and concrete block whilst I stood doing nothing. It is jarring and some battles become a duck shoot. The AI needs more work as it has turned the alien grunts and HECU into slightly timid enemies when they should be threats. On the other hand the assassins in game are agile but cause too much damage. This is being addressed by the developers but the levels with those enemies are almost unplayable. Its a shame as the enemy AI overall ranges from good (houndeyes and bullsquids) to bad (Ichthyosaur and alien grunts).

The set pieces in the game are still enjoyable and some are better than Half-Life. Most of the unforgiving insta-death moments in Half-Life are gone, but Black Mesa is still a lethal trial and error game in places. The On a Rail chapter is no longer a winding maze of rails and the Questionable Ethics and Lambda Core levels are really well done. Its a bit strange that with these improvements levels such as Residual Processing is still a bore and riding conveyor belts around with steep falls is plainly not fun. Surface Tension is also cut down so there is no sense of retreat by the HECU.

Deathmatch is in its early stages but a fun, chaotic, game which is more closer to HL2:DM than HL:DM. Olders players are complaining of the reduced movement but for me it is a fun distraction for a hour or two. Weapons are all solid and meaty and using the experimental weapons is still a lot of fun. Its death match so takes a lot of practice before you feel any ounce of skill.

How you view the entire package falls down if you have followed the development or not. If you have followed the project for a long time and want to award the devs for releasing the mod for free, then buy it on Steam. If you have been following the project and just want to play Xen then for now stick to the free mod version and wait. If you have not followed the project then I would suggest trying the free version for now as this is still being worked on.

I would recommend it based on the quality of other released games, however it is not Half Life, and needs tweaking. Let it mature a bit. The developers are still working on upgrading textures, tweaking multi-player and eventually bringing out Xen. I think it will be a few more years but hopefully a small monetary incentive will help them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What an amazing experience this is.

Back in 2012 when this game was still a mod I played the hell out of it. It is an amazing remake of the game that revolutionized the first person genre: Half Life. The game improves further on some aspects that weren’t even accessible back in the days which makes the story even more immersive. The game is completely cannon and adds some characters that are crucial to the Half Life Universe which weren’t in the first game. When Valve asked them to take the mod a step further and create a full retain copy I got super exited. They have not let me down, lots of improvements have been made to make this the remake it deserves to be. Better voice acting than the mod, new improved visuals and to top it all of a full Multiplayer Deathmatch.

More is coming though, Xen and as far as I heard they are experimenting with a CTF gamemode.

Absolutely a must have!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

## This version is well worth every dollar even if you already have played the original Black Mesa mod! ##

Huge improvements from the original free release, this is a absolute must for any Half-Life enthusiast! This is not just a huge graphical face lift for Half-Life it is almost a new game entirely! Pros: - Greatly improved and extremely immersive cinematic gameplay - Areas have been made larger, extreme attention to detail - Added physics engine puzzles found in Half-Life 2 replace most of the older outdated gameplay - Added facial muscle movement technology found in Half-Life 2 that still rivals most new titles of today - Well optimised graphics engine, runs very smoothly and looks stunning by even todays standards - New sound effects, new soundtrack, rescripted voice acting and newly improved weapon tweaks - Game now ties in well to Half-Life 2 subtly introducing characters of importance Cons: - Voice acting in parts could do with some work - Not yet finished, gameplay currently as of this point ends before the Zen stages (This game is in early access) - Typical Half-Life loading screens between main areas have not been removed

Black Mesa...My first 8 hours of gameplay made me so happy about the fact that it was a remastered version of Half-Life 1 that I could not stop playing... Until my energy collapsed :P

Well, where can I start?
Black Mesa is a remaster of Half-Life 1, the first game of the Half-Life franchise, made by Valve.
Not only a graphics remaster but a complete mechanics remaster, for those who don't know, Black Mesa, is a graphical/mechanical remasterization for HL 1.

It occurs in Texas, 1999 in the Black Mesa facility (oh, don't you say that, Sherlock) where a scientist named Gordon Freeman is about to test a new machine for his fellow scientists partners. I can't say more about the start because... It will be a huge spoiler and nobody likes that...

After a long while playing the free demo (a.k.a. not updated test version) version, I saw a lot of glitches, triggers you could walk past without activating them and... Buggy weapons... Of course there will be lots of bugs on the Demo (a.k.a NUTV (let's call it like that)) and it was a testing version leaked" for people to play and try the new mechanics.

Well

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What an absolutely fantastic game. Black Mesa is a re-imagining of the original Half Life, complete with improved AI, renovated maps, and a bright future ahead of it. The devs have been working on this for years and they deserve full props. I don't care if it isn't finished, it will be soon and you owe it to yourself as a PC gamer to buy this title.

On the well known source engine, most rigs will run this game. Complete with beautiful textures, models and a memorable soundtrack [questionable ethics intensifies] AND an array of community made mods to aid your nostalgic experience, you will surely find yourself having tons of fun, even if you've never touched a Half Life game before. 10/10.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black mesa. What a marvelous thing she is to behold. The wait time to get to this point has been long and frustrating. So many Half-Life 2 mods fail or fall into total obscurity and are never finished. This game is an example of a passion project by developers that simply won't quit until they accomplish the goals they set out to achieve.

It's a rich, detailed world they've created with the source engine, taking all the excitement and wonder of the original and turning the volume up to 11 with excellent level design and (mostly) clean crisp textures.

There are a lot of entitled people on the internet, people who will pay 60 dollars for their third copy of GTA 5 and pay a monthly fee for world of warcraft, but give them a total conversion for half-life 2 that reproduces the joy of the original half life for 1/3 the cost of a triple A title that also boasts a solid multiplayer experience? That's just unreasonable.

This game is worth twice the price, maybe more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not have any sort of nostalgia for Half-Life. I never played the first one, and I was unable to complete the second.

That being said, I've enjoyed alot of Black Mesa so far. The cast of characters are helpful and informative, giving the player incentive to save as many people as possible. They also engage in dialogue, and occasionally, the things they say to each other are profound and believable. The hard difficulty provides enough of a challenge without being too difficult. The enemies are tough, yet fair. The atmosphere and level design is reminicent of Bioshock (another game I hold dear).

Although I've given Black Mesa alot of praise, that does not mean it is without flaws. I ran into a couple of issues; the Vorts' AI seem to be broken during the Office Complex chapter (which I tested multiple times), the last few chapters are still in development, and occasionally, the HECU marine does not drop the shotgun like he is suppose to.

Overall, I LOVE this game, but I do not think it is worth the full price in it's current state. I suggest buying it durning a sale. I got my copy for $7.99US.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is just... unbelievable.

For those who don't want to read this really long review, just here are my quick thoughts: It's amazing; the graphics are amazing, the music is amazing, and the gameplay is amazing. It's worth every f***ing cent. Buy it right now.

Now for those who have nothing better to do with their time:

I first came in contact with the game back in 2008 when my sister's boyfriend talked to the both of us about it. I had become a fan of Half-Life already when I first saw Freeman's Mind and gradually became more and more addicted to the franchise as a whole. So, when I saw Black Mesa, I got really damn pumped, anxiously waiting for the 2009 release. Of course, as you now know, there were tons of delays. So many to the point that I thought the project would never get released. I came back and left and came back and left when looking at updates. I still was an avid fan and hoped for the better. It came as a shock to my friend and I when the original mod was released via Gamefront back in 2012, released at 8:47 A.M. mountain time. Now that's awesome.

This version on Steam is an Early-access version of the game that is recieving updates constantly and is yet to recieve the remaining Xen chapters. But from what I have played now for hours and hours, I can give my final thoughts. I don't even care of the Xen parts are crap, which I know they won't be, because as I fan and a critic, I can safely say this about the game:

It is better than the original Half-Life in every single way and is almost better than Half-Life 2 in some aspects. This is one of the best games I have played in years. It's hard to know where to start when analyzing this masterpiece but by just going through the basics, I guess. The level structures are beyond impressive. There was a lot of time and hard effort put into making this a realistic looking game and giving it a very, and again I say, realisitc look. The original game, because of its graphical limitations, wasn't that detailed, and thus, maps for levels were very blocky and designed in a linear manner. That made this Black Mesa facility look laughingly built like just a video game level. It kind of takes you out of the experience if you think about it. Black Mesa here on the other hand, adds lots of extra rooms, more details, extra desks in understandable locations, and objects that fit in certain locations. It is a gorgeous looking game, to say the least. I wish I could post screenshots here for examples.

So the level design is beyond outstanding. One of the best looking games out there, far better than Half-Life 2. The gameplay hasn't been altered much, but new HUD effects and animations for the guns have made the shooting action seem different from all other titles in the franchise. The weapons have a lot of good weight to them. You really feel like you're doing damage to the environment around you and the enemies you encounter along the way. However, there is a lot of hidden stuff and optional actions for the players to partake in that really add to the atmosphere of the game. While there was some of this in the original Half-Life, much more has been added into this game. For example, in the chapter Anamolous Materials"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been following Black Mesa from the time it still had the Source name in the title, over 6 years ago. I did not think it would actually be completed or released, let alone be such a loving, faithful homage to the original.

Let's be honest: Half-Life set the bar for a lot of things in its time but it hasn't aged well. The environments don't make much sense, enemy behaviour is erratic and there are only 4 scientists.

Black Mesa updates Half-Life, bringing in all the necessary 21st century sensibilities that the original lacked. At this point, if a friend of mine told me they wanted to start playing the Half-Life games, I'd tell them to start with Black Mesa and simply ignore the original. It is historically important, sure, but for the modern games BM is much more suitable (and less likely to drive them away from this classic series).

I can offer no higher praise for this game (I can't call it a mod" in good conscience) than to say it  And has surpassed its predecessor. And I am certain Valve agrees."

Early Access Review

The paid Steam release is the free release from a couple of years back with a number of jaw-dropping improvements to visual fidelity.... and a number of bugs the old free release didn't have, mostly relating to NPC meshes and quickloading so if you're one of those 1377d3wdz who plays on hard and hasn't died in an FPS since 1998 you'll never have most of the problems I experienced with the game.  The reflection mapping is cute but the fact that the player character does not reflect gave me a headache at first, as my art-brain was strenuously offended by such a glaring omission - though the PC does not exist" in most FPS in any meaningful way and that's entirely consistent with the original Half-Life.  As of May 2015 the developers seem to be focused on multiplayer so if you want the final act of the story you'll still need to play Half-Life: Source or the original Half-Life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, Black Mesa then...

Well, since I followed the development of this one from the early days, I felt 20 Euros (fifteen pounds) was a small price for the workmanship present here.

I haven't yet played the Multiplayer, as it's basically a TDM game, hopefully we'll get a classic free-for-all and co-op mode in the future, as it's something they promised early on, and a working multiplayer mode goes a long way to get a working co-operative game working.

From what I can see, the new animations are a lot nicer than the rather stiff ones previously found, and I like how the very first time you equip a weapon now plays a small animation, that's a nice touch, as for the combat anims themselves, they're also a lot nicer, with the Gauss Rifle actually shaking violently as you overcharge it.

The Deathmatch maps also look as I expected they would, without much deviation from the formula, which is nice, but there's no Datacore... yet.

If you're looking for a faithful remake of HL1 from the ground up, then you've found it.

If you're looking for something to whinge about, download the free version and be an entitled prick in the community section, either way, I enjoyed it, and I felt no shame in supporting the team for their decade of sweat and toil.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa Source is truly a faithful remake of the original Half Life. I do like the updated visuals, sounds, and the addition of the sprint feature from HL2. However, some of the character animations do look a bit stiff, and the head bobbing when strafing makes me get motion sickness after playing for an hour, though there is an option to turn off the head bobbing.

If you want to relive the nostalgic glory days of Half Life with updated visuals, this is it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS SO FUN.
I'M HAVING SO MUCH FUN.
OH MY GOD IT'S WONDERFUL!

Seriously though this game takes the mod - which was ALREADY brilliant - and makes things even more lovely.  Better visual effects.  Cleaner textures.  Slightly greater features.  Noticeably better gameplay.  Better sound quality with some charming vocal talents thrown in.  Don't even get me started on how much fast-paced fun the multiplayer is!  Just... augh, I LOVE THIS GAME.  And if you're a fan of the Half-Life series, you will too.

Now, let's pretend you've never heard of this mod or half-life.  Is it still worth your time?
Absolutely, yes.  This is not only a competent shooter, but one of the best in it's field.  Though not the prettiest shooter nor the most modern, it is extremely well put together, it handles magnificently, it has wonderful ideas (both from Valve's original and from the dev team), it's very well-characterized and it's one of the keystones of gaming upon which an era was founded.  You might not know it, but you probably need this game in your life.

Is it worth shelling out $20 when the mod is free?"
In every respect

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, so I've played through Black Mesa a few times ever since the initial mod release a couple years back.

Today was the day I was waiting for three years for: to see the mod finally up on Steam and having some semblance of progress towards a full release. I LOVE this mod, not because it simply updates the old Half-Life game...

No, this mod retells the story that Valve first told decades ago in the late 90s, much better, ironically, than they ever could have done. You don't play through the Black Mesa Incident anymore, you live through it. You don't simply stroll on in late to work, you stop and talk to people who know and work with you every day, people who all have their own relationships with you...

Which makes it all the more hard-hitting when the Resonance Cascade hits, and hits hard at that, and you are left to piece together what happened from the ashes not only your home, but the homes of many others. This is not a Half-Life remake, this is quite simply, what Half-Life is.

Now that my gushing over this amazing mod is out of the way, I'd like to take a moment to address the controversy" over this being a paid mod. Not a few weeks ago
date: the whole Skyrim Workshop debacle got me just as ruffled up as anyone else. It was a very flawed system
recommended: and I did everything I could to help contribute to getting the system removed. That said
hoursPlayed: BLACK MESA IS NOT WORKSHOPGATE 2.0!\n\nFor one
voteText: they've said for at least a year now that they would have a paid version on Steam
helpfulPercent: so it shouldn't be surprising to anyone who's actually followed the mod. Also
votesHelpful: you can still get the mod for free off their site. Finally
votesTotal: this game
votesFunny: and its very talented development team
commentsCount: deserves to be paid for. Not only has the Crowbar Collective matched Valve's quality
column16: it has surpassed it. For years
column17: this team has worked on this mod to retell one of the most influential stories in gaming's history
column18: and in my opinion
column19: their work is more than worthy of my hard-earned cash.\n\nAlso
column20: if you haven't gathered this so far
column21: the Crowbar Collective isn't some team of chuckles that simply makes mods
column22: they put love and effort into their work. Yes
column23: they may not work as fast as we want at times (believe me
column24: two years of waiting to see this mod finally up showed me that much)
column25: but they deliver something that is worth the wait.\n\nSo
column26: now that my review is done

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My Review on the new Black Mesa!


Positives!

+Breathtaking graphics for the Source Engine

+Addictive NEW multiplayer with two AMAZING gamemodes and more to come

+Best remake I and many others have played, it re-revolutionizes both the Singleplayer campaign and the Multiplayer gamemode(s), adding in two gamemodes from Half-Life: Opposing Force and Half-Life. It also has NEW and AWESOME weapon textures, Animations!

+NEW custom version of the Source Engine

+Workshop support, bringing new singleplayer and multiplayer maps to it by user generation.

+Modifiable, meaning players can use it's modified Source Engine and create new creations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Negatives...

-Countless small bugs, though it is in alpha. But still, this can be an issue [As of 5/9/15]

-Some large bugs like, sometimes maps will be fullbright though there is a fix, objects sometimes won't appear [Ex; Xen Trampolines], Custom models won't appear in multiplayer. [As of 5/9/15]

-No Xen [As of 5/9/15]

Fix for fullbright issues; [http://steamcommunity.com/app/362890/discussions/0/620712999974203382/]

Overall, this game is a 9.8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most intricate and dedicated game remake I've seen in my life.

The models and lighting look incredible in the newer Source engine, yet still keep a classic Half-Life vibe. The sound design, voice acting, and music are excellently done as well, with a beautiful musical score and crisp, clean sounds. Voice acting is also superb, and is mostly faithful to the original Half-Life, save for some improvements in acting quality.

Overall, it's a vast improvement over the original mod, and even includes multiplayer and addon/mod support through the Steam Workshop. If you loved Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and ESPECIALLY the original Black Mesa mod, this game is a must-buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played Half-Life 1 over and over again.
Played Half-Life: Source over and over again.
Played the mod version over and over again.
Will play this over and over again.

Very welcome updates and additions to the original mod, which was a very welcome and life-breathing to the original Half-Life.

I recommend this game to any Half-Life fans, but if you are going start the series anew, please go with the original Half-Life first. Not the BM mod, not HL:S. The original Half-Life.

This is due to the fact that Xen is not released yet, and you won't appreciate this as much as you would if you hadn't played the original yet.

It has a few performance issues, although I'm not sure if it's bsp leaks or something else, but it runs well above 60 FPS at highest graphic settings at 1366x768, with few dips below 50s when a fog heavy scene shows up which aren't that many really. One thing they have to fix is the Vsync. It refuses to work. I set it On" and it goes well beyond 70FPS in some places
date: sometimes going up to 80 and causing tearing.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having never played the original Half Life, this is an entirely fresh playthrough of the game with zero prior experience barring the playthroughs I pulled off on the original freeware version.

Let's just say this.

Black Mesa is leaps and bounds better than Half Life: Source.

Using the full power of the Source Engine to craft the game proprerly certainly shows here. Every aspect of the game is crafted with care and attention to detail.

Graphics are, dare I say it, better than what HL2 pulled off years ago.

Interactions and immersion into the game make you feel like a part of the game. This is backed up by the intense firefights that happen later on.

Sound design is brilliant.

Overall, a must buy if you want a great Half Life game. The price is well worth the playtime.

PS. Don't be fooled by the playtime. I've already done two playthroughs of the original mod. The game has gone far since those days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is truly well worked on. The attention to detail, voice acting, textures, fidelity to the story line, as well as the overall construction is amazing. There are very few structural and object placement changes (I confess I was feeling really uncomfortable not having the legendary crowbar where it used to be in the original Half-Life. It can be found slightly farther ahead now, but it's enough to make old timers break a sweat).

The game, overall, is incredible. It is Half-Life after all, isn't it? I'll just point out a few of the bad points. Take these off and you have yourselves a must-have recreation:

- I feel the hitboxes weren't thoroughly designed. Sometimes, a zombie will be able to hit you even if you're about 3 feet away from its reach, making crowbar fighting a quite tough experience; also, depending on the ongoing animation, clear headshots just won't register, and you'll find yourself wasting ammo that technically shouldn't have been wasted;

- I'm not sure whether more finale options have been added to this, as I have only tried it once. But where the hell is the Xen world? If there is one, I didn't get to set foot in it. It is pretty disappointing, as it is a big part of the original game.

- If you're reloading your shotgun from zero, make sure you switch weapons when you have 7 shells in. The pump action animation will invariably fire a round into whatever you're looking at. Switching weapons 'kills' the animation and prevents the accidental fire;

- Iron sights only work in the .357. It is a plus, although I don't remember it being a thing in the original Half-Life. However, it is pretty buggy. At first, it'll only work like the zoom in Counter-Strike (as though your neck has stretched some painful 2 feet forward). After a few seconds, the gun will line up in center just fine. The problem is, when you're not aiming anymore, it'll stay there, blocking your view of potentially important things until it's reloaded or switched for another weapon.

Either way, I'd totally recommend this revamped nostalgia streak for all veterans out there. Did I mention multiplayer is really fun?

Early Access Review

It´s hard to describe how cool is this game.

The first Half-Life was released around 98 and until today its considered by many (including me) the most impactant game ever.  After that there was so many cool mods, then we had Counter Strike, Steam, Portal, HL2, Source Engine and so many games related that changed and influenced the game industry forever, Half Life has much credit for that.

Black Mesa is a remake of the first Half-Life, made by a independent developer, and they did a incredible job. I played the free source version, but this is much improved. I read the reviews before buy and they are extremely positive but still the game exceed my expectations. They were very successful on preserve and improve the atmosphere and every thing that made HL so great, but still they improved so much the gameplay, puzzles and etc.  The Source physics are not only added, it really interact with the game.

Of course it´s not flawless, we have some problems specially with NPC and AI, but still awesome to play, and as early access maybe we yet get some improvement.

It´s pretty much like Half-Life 2, but Black Mesa facilities have a unique feeling, once you get inside there you will never forget.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is when the source engine is used at its best, by the best.. Black Mesa is a fantastic remake of VALVe's world famous 'Half-Life' (1998), with updated visuals, graphics and physics gameplay updating to modern day requirements. Black Mesa still captures the excitement and isolation the Half-Life created and takes you round the old Half-Life scenes and encounters, as well as polishing them up to the best standards. The new weapon models (My favourite being the Tau cannon), the textures and new NPC models make Black Mesa seem almost like a window into reality compared to Half-Life's old graphics.

One of my personal favourites of the improvements was that the HECU Marines did not speak through Radio's, but instead spoke normally in their voices. This immedietly made me more immersed and empathetic towards them, as you could hear their emotions through their voices for the first time, ranging from determined and aggressive to terrified and nervous. They did not have the bad-guy, kill em' all tone that they had in Half-Life but are now showing a more Human side. This was so effective that I even felt sorry killing the marines!

Black Mesa has also included a multiplayer gamemode, which uses some of the old maps multiplayer maps from half life 2, such as Gasworks and re-imagines them like the rest of the game. The multiplayer itself is a fun, enjoyable experience which has sucked a lot of my time into it. The fact multiplayer has been revived and focused on in such detail shows the amount of work and consideration being put into this project.

Unfortunately, the final Xen chapter is still going under development at crowbar collective. I predict that Xen will still have a while to go until it is ready for release. But the only possible outcome is that it will be outstanding and provide an excellent conclusion the this shining game. After all, the amount of work that was made to the main bulk of the game must surely tell us what Xen will be like!

I did encounter a small jigglebone bug with the scientists' ties and the Tau cannon pipe. They spasmed manically all the time and made the game a little funny. However, this did not turn out to be a major problem, as the game is centered more on yourself and personal experience than the involvement of NPC's and the use of certain weapons.

In conclusion, I take my hat of to Crowbar Collective and the other Dev's that are taking the time and contribution to this game and the amazing improvements they have made. I wish them the best for their futures and I give them a very big Thank you!

9.8/10

Early Access Review

Very nice remake.  The AI is a little wonky in some places.  For instance, in one of the later chapters, the aliens with the homing projectiles would just stand and stare at you.  Not much of a challenge.

These are small gripes when compared to how much I really enjoyed the new graphics.  I would certainly recommend this to anyone who wants to know what Half-Life is all about.

I was a little surprised that the game ended just before going to Xen, but then I realized the title of the game is Black Mesa."  Duh.

Final comment:  THANK YOU!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most intricate and dedicated game remake I've seen in my life.

The models and lighting look incredible in the newer Source engine, yet still keep a classic Half-Life vibe. The sound design, voice acting, and music are excellently done as well, with a beautiful musical score and crisp, clean sounds. Voice acting is also superb, and is mostly faithful to the original Half-Life, save for some improvements in acting quality.

Overall, it's a vast improvement over the original mod, and even includes multiplayer and addon/mod support through the Steam Workshop. If you loved Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and ESPECIALLY the original Black Mesa mod, this game is a must-buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people are probably ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about this being a paid-for product, but that's because it was initially labelled as a mod. As it stands, it's not a mod. It's a full-on remake, and a damned good one at that. The level design stays fairly true to the original, but it takes some liberties that make use of the newer Source engine.

I also had the opportunity to accidentally do a side-by-side test between a new PC and a 6 year old PC, since I just upgraded. Performance on the older computer was pretty good, with a few hiccups here and there (it was also running on an external drive, which undoubtedly impacted performance), and ran flawlessly on the new PC. Since the Source engine is older than that PC, that's probably to be expected.

The elephant in the room has to be the lack of a Xen chapter. I'm given to understanding that this is part of the reason it's in Early Access, which makes sense. They're also not discussing development of the chapter, so when it comes out it comes out, I suppose. As it stands, I recommend the game. I'll probably recommend it even more after Xen is released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It´s hard to describe how cool is this game.

The first Half-Life was released around 98 and until today its considered by many (including me) the most impactant game ever.  After that there was so many cool mods, then we had Counter Strike, Steam, Portal, HL2, Source Engine and so many games related that changed and influenced the game industry forever, Half Life has much credit for that.

Black Mesa is a remake of the first Half-Life, made by a independent developer, and they did a incredible job. I played the free source version, but this is much improved. I read the reviews before buy and they are extremely positive but still the game exceed my expectations. They were very successful on preserve and improve the atmosphere and every thing that made HL so great, but still they improved so much the gameplay, puzzles and etc.  The Source physics are not only added, it really interact with the game.

Of course it´s not flawless, we have some problems specially with NPC and AI, but still awesome to play, and as early access maybe we yet get some improvement.

It´s pretty much like Half-Life 2, but Black Mesa facilities have a unique feeling, once you get inside there you will never forget.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is truly well worked on. The attention to detail, voice acting, textures, fidelity to the story line, as well as the overall construction is amazing. There are very few structural and object placement changes (I confess I was feeling really uncomfortable not having the legendary crowbar where it used to be in the original Half-Life. It can be found slightly farther ahead now, but it's enough to make old timers break a sweat).

The game, overall, is incredible. It is Half-Life after all, isn't it? I'll just point out a few of the bad points. Take these off and you have yourselves a must-have recreation:

- I feel the hitboxes weren't thoroughly designed. Sometimes, a zombie will be able to hit you even if you're about 3 feet away from its reach, making crowbar fighting a quite tough experience; also, depending on the ongoing animation, clear headshots just won't register, and you'll find yourself wasting ammo that technically shouldn't have been wasted;

- I'm not sure whether more finale options have been added to this, as I have only tried it once. But where the hell is the Xen world? If there is one, I didn't get to set foot in it. It is pretty disappointing, as it is a big part of the original game.

- If you're reloading your shotgun from zero, make sure you switch weapons when you have 7 shells in. The pump action animation will invariably fire a round into whatever you're looking at. Switching weapons 'kills' the animation and prevents the accidental fire;

- Iron sights only work in the .357. It is a plus, although I don't remember it being a thing in the original Half-Life. However, it is pretty buggy. At first, it'll only work like the zoom in Counter-Strike (as though your neck has stretched some painful 2 feet forward). After a few seconds, the gun will line up in center just fine. The problem is, when you're not aiming anymore, it'll stay there, blocking your view of potentially important things until it's reloaded or switched for another weapon.

Either way, I'd totally recommend this revamped nostalgia streak for all veterans out there. Did I mention multiplayer is really fun?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having never played the original Half Life, this is an entirely fresh playthrough of the game with zero prior experience barring the playthroughs I pulled off on the original freeware version.

Let's just say this.

Black Mesa is leaps and bounds better than Half Life: Source.

Using the full power of the Source Engine to craft the game proprerly certainly shows here. Every aspect of the game is crafted with care and attention to detail.

Graphics are, dare I say it, better than what HL2 pulled off years ago.

Interactions and immersion into the game make you feel like a part of the game. This is backed up by the intense firefights that happen later on.

Sound design is brilliant.

Overall, a must buy if you want a great Half Life game. The price is well worth the playtime.

PS. Don't be fooled by the playtime. I've already done two playthroughs of the original mod. The game has gone far since those days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa was originally a Source Engine mod which was released to the public back in 2012, but was announced a number of years previously.

Considering that Black Mesa was made by a group of modders, the game has significantly overshadowed other Source Engine mods in terms of quality.

Black Mesa can be compared to many AAA 8th Generation titles which are released currently. High graphical fidelity as well as gameplay that is similar to many shooter titles today.

Is Black Mesa good? Yes, in fact I'd say that it's better than the original Half Life. There are a number of elements of Half Life which no longer hold up, most of which have been removed, reworked or reimagined entirely to fit in much better in the game. The attention to detail will make you remember the original Half Life in a more favourable way. I have only one complaint, that Residue Processing is still as horrible with its platforming as ever, that's it. Surface Tension is however much better in execution. Tanks are mobile, appear 3 times and have a much more challenging AI. Infantry Fighting Vehicles also debut, but appear once. Snipers are better and are modified versions of the Combine snipers of HL2.
As far as I can tell, gameplay is enhanced and that elements from HL2 gameplay is adapted while staying true to the original HL gameplay.

Xen is missing from the game at time of writing this review. Apparently the plan is to totally overhaul the Xen levels in order to make them more playable and provide a superior player experience.

The game up until that point is very much polished. There is very little to fault the game with. Perhaps a lack of voice actors (I suspect something like 6 were used). The player is also sometimes prone to getting stuck in invisible objects (time to brush up on console commands and noclip) but now I'm nitpicking.

I recommend Black Mesa for all those who played the original Half Life and want to relive the game with modern graphics and modern gameplay. I also recommend Black Mesa to those who have never played Half Life. It permits players to experience the original game with the original plot line, but experience it in a modern way in line with many other games released today.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1. This is a bunch of talented fans, that started as hobbyists and have gone on to form an official studio, we should be applauding that and wishing them every success. The system works. That’s the dream.
2. Black Mesa is ridiculously polished and professional for a fan-made game.
3. They dabbled with a franchise that’s like the Holy Grail of PC gaming and pulled it off to mostly praise. That’s practically miraculous.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having never played the original Half Life, this is an entirely fresh playthrough of the game with zero prior experience barring the playthroughs I pulled off on the original freeware version.

Let's just say this.

Black Mesa is leaps and bounds better than Half Life: Source.

Using the full power of the Source Engine to craft the game proprerly certainly shows here. Every aspect of the game is crafted with care and attention to detail.

Graphics are, dare I say it, better than what HL2 pulled off years ago.

Interactions and immersion into the game make you feel like a part of the game. This is backed up by the intense firefights that happen later on.

Sound design is brilliant.

Overall, a must buy if you want a great Half Life game. The price is well worth the playtime.

PS. Don't be fooled by the playtime. I've already done two playthroughs of the original mod. The game has gone far since those days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a really great experience so far.

Black Mesa is still a labyrinth with great pacing between combat, exploration, and puzzle solving, and with the same array of weapons... but with lots of modern twists. The HDR lighting is beautiful, the art assets look better than Half-Life 2, combat feels much better, and the new Soundtrack is great (it gives chapters like Blast Pit a whole different feel).

On top of that, there's lots of extra ties and references to future Half-Life games, and the dev team themselves. Clearly a lot of love and attention to detail went into development, and the result is a mod that plays better than most AAA games.

NOTE: This is indeed still early access. You may want to hold out for Xen before buying, but I didn't have the patience, and am loving it so far.

Early Access Review

I competed the game so far (untill next release). I have to say i was quite impressed. At first I was hesitant due to being a 20$ price on it, so i went through the reviews, weighing the pro's and con's then realized something. This 20$ goes to time spent plus helping the developers be able to focus on the game. SO I hope they complete the final chapter. So it took me 10 hours of play to get through it. I died a LOT. With the way the AI is writting, cannot just go out guns blazing dodging left/right taking cover here and there. I found myself taking cover and waiting for them to come to me as the game progressed.

With HL, it was easy to get through the levels and figure out the path to take or solve the puzzle. WIth Black Mesa it wasnt so obvious, due to how detailed the game is, so the answer just doesnt stand out".

There were moments im going to go back and play through

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is about incidentally bumping into your ex girlfriend whilst visiting another town. You end up having a coffee together and because it feels just like old times, lauging, chatting all the time, you decide to have dinner later that night. You meet at a cosy Sushi place which is a typical place where you used to go when you were together a few years ago. The Sake flowing richly through the evening you discover your hotels are only a few hundred feet from eachother. After fantastic sushi you decide to go for one more drink at her hotel room. Emptying half of the mini bar, you end up having the greatest sex, just like you remembere it to be.

And that is what this game is: like meeting your ex girlfriend and experience all the best you once had all over again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everyone has made the mistake of watching that favorite childhood movie again once they are a bit older, ruining all the fond memories of those awesome action scenes turned worse-than-corny with age.

Black Mesa is nothing like that, letting you re-live and re-experience your first moments the classic game we know and love in stunning quality and with the best gameplay.

It is the first truly worthy remake of its kind and it took me all of three seconds to decide to buy it once it was available.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A glorious revival of a cult classic, the product of a decade of hard work - this is Black Mesa. Almost every asset in the game was built from the ground up and it shows - it doesn't just feel like you are replaying Half-Life with improved textures and models, in fact, you could be forgiven for thinking Valve themselves recreated their own game the first time you play Black Mesa. Oh, and did I mention it has multiplayer?

Speaking of Valve, let Black Mesa show them that the Half-Life fanbase is still very much alive and eagerly waiting for the next official installment in the franchise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I handed a man toilet paper.

I AM THE HERO BLACK MESA NEEDS

________________________________________________________________

Black Mesa is Half-Life. That's really all that can be said about it in one sentence. However, it is much better than the official Source port of Half-Life. The developers hand-made each texture, voiced each character, and coded each segment. The only things the developers used that they didn't make were the plot and overall concept. My favorite part was, well, Black Mesa. I loved going into all of the new rooms and interacting with things and hearing all of the extra dialogue. After that, it's just Half-Life. If you've played it, you've pretty much played this. In my eyes that's a downfall, though not a very big one. If you have Half-Life: Source and wanted a REAL Source port, this is for you. I haven't played the multiplayer that much, but from what I've seen it's Deathmatch: Source, but again, actually in Source.

I rate the game overall 9.5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like many others, I've played quite a bit of the free mod version of Black Mesa. I do like the original Half Life, a game that still seems to hold up today in terms of story detail (not necessarily being thrown directly at your face), but I've been spoiled by much prettier games for far too long.

Black Mesa is exactly what it is setting out to be: A complete re-make of Half Life in the Source engine with more detailed environments, much better lighting, shadows, textures, and visual effects as a result. The game will be entirely familiar to anyone who played the original game, and is a great way for people who have never played it before to give it a go.
At this point however, it's still missing Xen, an arguably weaker portion of the game, but still a portion of it regardless. Many were hoping, myself included, that the Steam release would finally see this part of the game included. Instead, it seems we got multiplayer for now.

This is easily one of the best looking Source games (unless you count the heavily modified version used in something like Titanfall) and it runs exactly like a source engine game. My system can run the game with full max settings at 4K resolution AND AA enabled at 60FPS no problem at all. Gameplay is smooth, very similar to Half Life 2, and keeps all the exact same mechanics.

The atmosphere was nailed perfectly. Obviously with the leap in engine and technology from the original, this game manages to have much better atmosphere than Half Life, with the previously mentioned better lighting and shadows, causing a more drastic and dramatic change to the Black Mesa facility after the incident". Sound is fantastic as well. Something about that heavy
date: boot thud after falling down from something is very satisfying to me. All the gun models look fantastic and sound just as great
recommended: packing real punch.\n\nIt's really quite amazing how accurate this game is to the original
hoursPlayed: from item and environment placement to the same character voices
voteText: all while managing to add their own detail as well that feels entirely appropriate.\n\nIs it worth your $20 right now? Well
helpfulPercent: it's in Early Access right now for a reason: It's incomplete. My thought is that they developers are trying to gain a few bucks now so they can speed up the process on creating the remainder of the game
votesHelpful: so if you want to support the developers
votesTotal: and to have much easier access to the game (rather than torrenting it and having to download the SDK) then go ahead. Otherwise
votesFunny: wait until it's out of E.A. We've waited this long already. What's a little longer?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As I am constantly replaying the game or sections this  review has been updated as of: 5/30/16
In it's current state Black Mesa impressive but there's some awful lag on multiplayer (There are more people playing Richochet too come to think of it and by that I mean one person.) and the game still requires a little more polish as things are a little glitchy (Also the marines STILL sound awful even after getting a new voice actor to redo all the dialogue.) The weapons really need to be exactly like they were in Half-Life because strangely (And I'm not the most nitpicky I swear.) the small changes made to how they work just make them not very fun to use. The comabt is kinda dull. Before an update May 14th here is how I felt about two important enemy types you'll encounters remade incarnations: What it really needs to do is fix the soldiers as they are not as intelligent or as fun to fight as their GoldSource counter parts..." While the HECU's mod AI had a jaw dropping aimbot and firing rate which did get fixed in the retail version but even still before the update the soldiers acted less like real humans or the HECU and more like reskinned combine in terms of behavior. As of the update currently the HECU run away
date: group up and spread out a lot more than before AND even make meangful hand signals which is a big improvement even though they aren't as smart as their Gold Source and Half-Life: Source counterparts YET. I've seen soldiers try and sometimes suceed in distracting me with supressing fire after gesturing a soldier to try to move up to my position which having check the console was done by  the AI and not thanks to a triggered scripted sequence. Effectivley they will sometimes try to sneak up on you in an unscripted manner. The Vortiguants now have similar timing for charging and aiming their lazers where as before in the 2012 mos they completley missed the point of their Half-Life counterparts having a charge up times. The only problem now is that you can dodge their attacks without getting behind cover like in Half-Life and can simply strafe right or left. On another dour note the Source engine is really starting to show it's age as these remade visuals are ( a wee bit) inconsistant in terms of quality. I feel some sort of Ultra option for textures and models should be added to uncompress the textures or use 2048x2048 resolution textures and higher poly versions of the models that having followed the games development I know they have. I would even suggest adding an "r_lod 0" option to the video settings so as to minimize whatever pop or lod shifts there are. Some of the faces look great while others look more dated than the faces from Half-Life 2 which might I add have aged quite well even more so for 2004. Even with all of that said this is probably the best game on early access right now and this iteration improves greatly apon the 2012 mod version. The development is slow but it's a fun
recommended: shiny version of Half-Life. Not everyone will be able to enjoy a game thats aged as well gameplay wise as Half-Life or get immeresed thanks to the visuals like I was and still am making this a must play for newcomers intersted in the series. Xen is missing too because it's in alpha but honestly thats a blessing in disguise. ;)"

Early Access Review

I played the original mod version of Black Mesa the instant it came out a couple of years ago and loved it!

Already started my second playthough, this time with the Steam edition and have to say it's just as good as I remember, if not even better. I feel little bits and bats have been added along the way but nothing really stands out as a change. I suppose this is a good thing really, it's not easy to improve on near perfection! I am also recording a let's play over on my YouTube channel.

Overall, I have to say, Black Mesa is a near perfect Half-Life reboot. I doubt even Valve could have done a much better job. Now, with all the hype recently about Paid Mods"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A remarkable remake of one of the most defining gaming experience ever made.
This game shows so much love and effort put into it and it really makes you feel nostalgic while being an excellent advancement of the core game mechanics half life introduced back in the days.

Regarding the early access state.
The last portion of the game is currently missing. But it was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the original game, so the devs decided to remake the whole chapter, making it better and more fun to play.
If you want to experience the whole game I advice you to wait a little bit longer.

But if you like old school shooters, regardless of whether you played the original half life or not, you have to play Black Mesa any time soon.
You won't be disappointed.

Crowbar/10
